tgt_text.2498: She gave the bow and quiver (the emblems of the god under whom he served) to Theagenes to bear:
tgt_text.2500: They now approached the lake, and were preparing to get into a boat, when they saw a company of armed men passing over toward the island.
tgt_text.2501: Rendered dizzy by the sight, they stood for some time astounded, as if deprived of all feeling by the continued assaults of unwearied evil fortune.
tgt_text.2502: At last, however, and just as the men were landing, Chariclea proposed to retire again into the cave, and endeavour to conceal themselves there;
tgt_text.2503: and was running towards it, when Theagenes stopped her, and exclaimed, “Why should we vainly endeavour to fly from that fate which pursues us every where?
tgt_text.2504: Let us yield to our fortune, and meet it with fortitude:
tgt_text.2505: what besides should we gain but unending troubles, a wandering life, and still renewed assaults of the evil genius who mocks and persecutes us ?
tgt_text.2506: Have you not experienced how he has added, with savage eagerness, the assaults of pirates to exile, and worse perils by land to those we suffered by sea;
tgt_text.2507: how he terrified us first with fightings, afterwards threw us into the hands of buccaneers, detained us some time in captivity, then left us solitary and deserted, just gave us a prospect of flight and freedom, and now sends ruffians to destroy us;
tgt_text.2508: plays off his warfare against us and our fortunes, and gives them the appearance of a continually shifting scene, and sadly varied drama?
tgt_text.2509: Let us put an end then to the tragedy, and give ourselves up to those who are prepared for our destruction, lest the con­ tinued pressure and increase of our misfortunes oblige us, at last, to lay violent hands upon ourselves.
tgt_text.2510: ”Chariélea did not entirely agree with all which her lover in his passion said.
tgt_text.2511: She admitted the justice of his expos­ tulations with fortune, but could not see the propriety of giving themselves up into the hands of the armed men.
tgt_text.2512: It was not certain that they meant to destroy them;
tgt_text.2513: the evil genius who pursued them would not, perhaps, be kind enough to put so quick an end to their miseries ;
tgt_text.2514: he probably reserved them to experience the hardships of servitude;
tgt_text.2515: and was it not worse than death to be exposed to the insults and indignities of the barbarians P “Let us endeavour, there­ fore, Of said she, “by all means in our power to avoid this fate.
tgt_text.2516: We may, from past experience, have some hopes of success:
tgt_text.2517: we have frequently, already, escaped from dangers which appeared inevitable.
tgt_text.2519: “Let us do as you please," said Theagenes;
tgt_text.2520: and followed her, unwillingly, as she led the way.
tgt_text.2521: They could not, how­ ever, escape in safety to the cave;
tgt_text.2522: for while they were looking only at the enemy in front, they were not aware of another troop which had landed on a different part of the island, and which was taking them from behind, as in a net.*
tgt_text.2523: They were now utterly confounded, and stood still, Chariclea keeping close by Theagenes, so that if they were to die they might die together.
tgt_text.2524: Some of the men who approached were just preparing to strike;
tgt_text.2525: but when the youthful pair, looking up, flashed upon them the full splen­ dour of their beauty, their hearts failed them, and their hands grew slack;
tgt_text.2526: for the arm even of a barbarian reverences the beautiful, and the fiercest eye grows milder before a lovely countenance.
tgt_text.2527: They took them prisoners, therefore, and conducted them to their leader, anxious to lay before him the first and fairest of the spoils.
tgt_text.2528: It was the only booty, however, which they were likely to obtain, for they could find nothing else, after the strictest search throughout the island.
tgt_text.2529: Everything on the surface of it had been destroyed by the late conflagration.
tgt_text.2530: They were ignorant of the cave and its contents.
tgt_text.2531: They proceeded then towards their com­ mander:
tgt_text.2532: he was Mithranes, commandant to Oroondates, viceroy of Egypt, under the Great King, whom Nausicles (as has been said) had induced, by a great sum of money, to make this expedition into the island in search of Thisbe.
tgt_text.2533: Upon the approach of Theagenes and Chariclea, Nausicles, with the quick-sighted craft of a merchant, started forward, and running up, exclaimed, “This is indeed Thisbe, the very Thisbe ravished from me by those villain pirates, but restored by your kindness, Mithranes, and by the gods."
tgt_text.2534: He then caught hold of Chariclea, and seemed in an ecstacy of joy;
tgt_text.2535: at the same time he spoke to her pri­ vately in Greek, in a low voice, and bid her, if she valued her life, pretend that her name was Thisbe.
tgt_text.2537: Chariclea, pleased at hearing her native language, and flattering herself with the hopes of comfort and assistance from the man who spoke it, did as he bid her;
tgt_text.2538: and when Mithranes asked her her name, said it was Thisbe.
tgt_text.2539: Nausicles then ran up to Mithranes, kissed his head, flattered the barbarian's vanity, extolled his good fortune, and congratulated him that,besides his many other exploits, this expedition had bad such good success.
tgt_text.2540: He, cajoled by these praises, and really believing the truth of what was said (being deceived by the natne), though smitten with the beauty of the maiden, which shone out under a sorry garb, like the moon- from beneath a cloud;
tgt_text.2541: yet, confounded by the quickness of Nausicles's manœuvres, and having no time given to his fickle mind for change of pur­ pose, said, " Take, then, this maiden, whom my arms have recovered for you;
tgt_text.2542: " and so saying, he delivered her into his hands, unwillingly and frequently looking back upon her, as if he would not have parted with her had he not thought himself pledged, by the reward he had received, to give her up.
tgt_text.2543: "But as for her companion," he added, pointing to Theagenes, “he shall be my prize.
tgt_text.2544: Let him follow me under a guard;
tgt_text.2545: he shall be sent to Babylon:
tgt_text.2546: with such a figure as his, he will become the service of the great king."
tgt_text.2547: And having thus signified his pleasure, they passed over the lake, and were separated from each other.
tgt_text.2548: Nausicles took the road to Chemmis, with Chariclea;
tgt_text.2549: Mithranes visited some other towns which were under his command, and very soon sent Theagenes to Oroondates, who was then at Mem­ phis, accompanied with the following letter:
tgt_text.2551: I have taken prisoner a Grecian youth of too noble an appearance to continue in my service, and worthy to appear before, and serve only, the Great King.
tgt_text.2552: I send him to von, that you may offer him to our common master, as a great and inestimable present, such a one as the royal court has never yet beheld, and probably never will again.
tgt_text.2553: "Scarcely had the day dawned when eager curiosity carried Calasiris and Cnemon to the apartment of Nausicles, to inquire farther into his adventures.
tgt_text.2554: He told them all that I have related:
tgt_text.2555: how he arrived at the island;
tgt_text.2557: the deceit he had put upon Mithranes, in passing off another maiden upon him for Thisbe;
tgt_text.2558: he was better pleased, he said, with his present prize than if he had really found Thisbe;
tgt_text.2559: there was no more comparison between their several beauties than between a mortal and a goddess;
tgt_text.2560: hers was unrivalled, it was impossible for hint to express how beautiful she was;
tgt_text.2561: but, as she was under his roof, they might satisfy themselves with their own eyes.
tgt_text.2562: When they heard this, they began to suspect a little of the truth, and besought him to send for her immediately, as knowing that words could not do justice to her personal appearance.
tgt_text.2563: When she was introduced (with downcast eyes, and her face veiled to her forehead), and Nausicles had besought her to be of good cheer, she looked up a little, and saw (beyond her hopes), and was seen by, her unexpected friends.
tgt_text.2564: Immediately a sudden cry was heard from all.
tgt_text.2565: These exclamations burst out at once, “My father!”—“ My daughter!
tgt_text.2568: Nausicles stood mute with astonishment when he saw CaIn­ siris embracing Chariclea, and weeping for joy.
tgt_text.2569: He won­ dered what this could be which had the air of a recognition on the stage, when Calasiris ran to him, and embracing him, cried out, " 0 best of men, may the gods shower on you every blessing you desire, as you have been the pre­ server of my daughter, and have restored to my longing eyes the delight of my life.
tgt_text.2572: She wept at the ques­ tion, and, pausing a little, said, " He who delivered me to this gentleman, whoever he may be, has led him away cap­ tive."
tgt_text.2573: Calasiris besought Nausicles to discover to turn all ho knew about Theagenes;
tgt_text.2574: under whose power he now was;
tgt_text.2575: and whither they had taken him.
tgt_text.2576: The merchant gave him all the information he was able, conceiving this to be the pair about whom he had frequently heard the old man speak, and whom he knew he was seeking in sorrow.
tgt_text.2577: He added, that he feared his intelligence would not be of much service to persons in their humble circum­ stances;
tgt_text.2578: he doubted, indeed, whether any sum of money would induce Mithranes to part with the youth.
tgt_text.2579: a We are rich enough," said Chariclea softly to Calasiris;
tgt_text.2580: " promise him as much as you please;
tgt_text.2581: I have preserved the necklace which you know of, and have it with me."
tgt_text.2582: Calasiris reco­ vered his spirits at hearing this;
tgt_text.2583: but not choosing to let Nausicles into the secret of their wealth, replied, " My good Nausicles, the wise man is never poor;
tgt_text.2584: he measures his de­ sires by his possessions, and receives from those who abound what it is honourable for him to ask.
tgt_text.2585: Tell us then where the person is who has Theagenes in his power;
tgt_text.2586: the divine goodness will not be wanting to us, but will supply us with as much as is sufficient to satisfy the avarice of this Persian.
tgt_text.2587: "Nausicles smiled incredulously. " I shall," said he, “be persuaded that you can suddenly grow rich, as by a miracle, when you have first paid down to me a ransom for this maiden;
tgt_text.2588: you know that riches have as many charms for a merchant as for a Persian.”—“ I know it," replied the old man, "and you shall have a ransom.
tgt_text.2589: But why do you not anticipate my wishes, and, with your customary bene­ volence, offer, of your own accord, to restore my daughter ?
tgt_text.2590: Must I be forced to entreat it of you ?”—“ You shall have her on proper terms," said the merchant. " I do not grudge you her;
tgt_text.2591: but now (as I am going to sacrifice) let us join in supplication to the gods, and pray that they would increase my wealth, and bestow some on you.”—“ Spare your ridi­ cule," replied Calasiris, " and be not incredulous;
tgt_text.2592: make preparations for the sacrifice, and we will attend you when everything is ready.
tgt_text.2593: "Nausicles agreed to this, and soon after sent a message to his guests to desire their presence.
tgt_text.2594: They obeyed cheer­ fully, having before concerted what they were to do.
tgt_text.2595: The men accompanied Nausicles to the altar, with many others who were invited, for it was a public sacrifice.
tgt_text.2596: Chariclea went with the merchant's daughter and some other females, whose encouragements and entreaties had prevailed upon her to be present at the ceremony;
tgt_text.2597: and they would hardly have persuaded her had she not secretly pleased herself with the thought of taking this opportunity to pour out her vows and prayers for Theagenes.
tgt_text.2598: They came to the temple of Mercury (for him, as the god of gain and merchants, Nausicles particularly worshipped) ;
tgt_text.2599: and when the sacred rites were performed, Calasiris inspect­ ing the entrails of the victim, and changing his countenance according as they portended joyful or adverse events, at last stretched out his hand, (murmuring certain words) and pre. tending to take something from among the ashes, presented a ring of great value to Nausicles, which he had brought with him for that purpose :
tgt_text.2600: “And here,” said he, " the gods, by my hands, offer you this as a ransom for Chariclea.
tgt_text.2601: ”The ring - was a perfect marvel, both for material and workmanship.
tgt_text.2602: The circle was of electrum, within the bezil † was an Æthiopian amethyst, of the size of a maiden's eye, finer much than those of Spain or Britain ;
tgt_text.2603: for these latter have a dullish tinge of purple, like a rose just bursting from its bud, and beginning to redden under the sun's beams;
tgt_text.2604: whereas the Æthiopian amethyst shines with a deeper and more sparkling lustre;
tgt_text.2605: if you turn it about it scatters its rays on all sides, not dulling but lighting up the sight.
tgt_text.2606: “They are besides of much greater virtue than the western ones ;
tgt_text.2607: they do not belie their name, ‡ but will really keep those who wear them sober amid great excesses.
tgt_text.2608: This property is common to all the Indian and Æthiopian stones:
tgt_text.2609: but that which Calasiris now gave Nausicles far surpassed them.
tgt_text.2610: It was carved with wonderful art, and represented a shepherd tending his sheep.
tgt_text.2611: He sat upon a rock, gently elevated from the ground, surveying his flock, and distribut­ ing them § into different pastures by the various notes of his pipe;
tgt_text.2612: they seemed to obey, and to feed as the sound directed them.
tgt_text.2613: You would say that they had golden fleeces, the natural blush of the amethyst, without the aid of art, casting a glow upon their backs.
tgt_text.2614: Here you might observe the frolics of the little lambs;
tgt_text.2615: some climbing up the ascent, others gambolling around the shepherd, converted the rock into a pastoral theatre.
tgt_text.2616: Some wantoning in the flame of the gem as in the sun, just touched in bounding the rocky surface;
tgt_text.2617: others, older and more bold, seemed as if they would overleap the circle;
tgt_text.2618: but here art had hindered them, and surrounded the jewel in the rock with the golden bezil.
tgt_text.2619: The rock was not counterfeit, but real;
tgt_text.2620: the artist, to represent it, had inclosed the edges of the stone, and was not put to the trouble of feigning what in reality existed.
tgt_text.2622: Nausicles was struck at the seeming miracle, and de­ lighted with the beauty of the gem, which he esteemed to be of more value than all he was worth.—“
tgt_text.2623: I was but jesting," said he, "my dear Calasiris, when I talked of a ransom for your daughter;
tgt_text.2624: my design was to restore her to you freely;
tgt_text.2626: but since, as they say, the gifts of the gods are not to be refused, I accept this jewel which is sent from heaven;
tgt_text.2627: persuaded that it is a present from Mercury, the best of deities, who has furnished you with it through the fire, and indeed you see how it sparkles itself with flames :
tgt_text.2628: besides, I think that the pleasantest and most lawful gain is that which, without impoverishing the giver, enriches the receiver.
tgt_text.2629: "Having said this, he took the ring, and proceeded with the rest of the company to an entertainment;
tgt_text.2630: the women by themselves, in the interior of the temple;
tgt_text.2632: When they had satisfied their appetite, and the board was crowned with cups, they sang a suitable * hymn to Bacchus, and poured out libations to him;
tgt_text.2633: the women sang an hymn of thanksgiving to Ceres.
tgt_text.2634: Chariclea, retiring from the rest, occupied with her own thoughts, prayed for the health and safe return of Tbeagenes.
tgt_text.2635: And now, the company being warmed with wine, and rife with mirth, Nausicles, holding out a goblet of pure water, said, " Good Calasiris, let us offer this to the nymphs, the sober nymphs your deities, who have no sympathy with Bacchus, and are nymphs in very deed;
tgt_text.2636: but if you will entertain us with such a relation as we wish to hear, it will be more pleasant to us than even our flowing bowls.
tgt_text.2637: You see the women have already risen from the table, and are amusing themselves with dancing;
tgt_text.2638: but neither dancing nor music will be so pleasant to us as the narrative of your wanderings, if you will favour us with it.
tgt_text.2639: You have often excused yourself from the task on account of the troubles with which you were overwhelmed, and the lowness of your spirits;
tgt_text.2640: but there cannot be a more proper time for it than the present, when everything contributes to remove the one and to raise the other.
tgt_text.2641: You have recovered your daughter, and bavo hopes of recovering your son;
tgt_text.2642: especially if you do not affront me, by deferring your story any longer.
tgt_text.2643: "Now may all good attend you, Nausicles," said Cnemon, putting in his word;
tgt_text.2644: who, although you have provided all manner of music for our recreation, are willing to forego such delights (leaving them to ordinary minds), and to listen to higher and mysterious matters, seasoned with a divine interest.
tgt_text.2645: You snowjudgment in coupling together the deities, Mercury and Bacchus, thus mingling the pleasures of discourse with those of wine.
tgt_text.2646: Though I admire the whole order of this splendid sacrifice, yet I know nothing which will render the god of eloquence more propitious, than if this good old man will contribute his narrative * to the rest of the entertainment.
tgt_text.2647: "Calasiris obeyed, as well to oblige Cnemon, as to con­ ciliate the favour of Nausicles, whose f services he fore­ saw he should have occasion for, and entered upon his story.
tgt_text.2648: He began with what he had already related to Cnemon;
tgt_text.2649: he was now, however, less minute, and entirely passed over some matters which he did not choose Nausicles to know;
tgt_text.2650: and when he had proceeded to the point where he had before left off,‡ be went on as follows :
tgt_text.2652: As the wind was at first very favourable to us, the fugi­ tives from Delphi began to flatter themselves with the hopes of a prosperous voyage;
tgt_text.2653: but when we got into the straits of Calydon,§ the swell and rolling of the waves alarmed them not a little;
tgt_text.2654: " here Cnemon, interrupting, begged him to explain, if he could, the cause of that agitation. “ The Ionian sea," continued Calasiris, “from being wide beyond, is there contracted, and pours itself, by a narrow channel, into the Crissæan gulf;
tgt_text.2655: whence, hastening to mingle its waters with the Ægean, it is stopped and thrown back again by the Isthmus of Peloponnesus;
tgt_text.2656: which is opposed, probably, as a rampart by divine providence, lest it should overflow the opposite land:
tgt_text.2657: and a greater reflux being occasioned in the strait than in the rest of the gulf, from the encounter of the advancing and retreating tides the waves, owing to .
tgt_text.2658: this repercussion, boil, swell, and break in tumult one over the other."
tgt_text.2659: This explanation was received with the applause and approbation of all;
tgt_text.2660: and the old man continued his narration.“
tgt_text.2661: Having passed the strait, and lost sight of the Oxinn * Isles, we thought we discovered the promontory of Za­ cynthus, which rose on our sight like an obscure cloud, and the pilot gave orders to furl the sails.
tgt_text.2662: We inquired why he slackened the vessel's speed, when we had a prosperous wind :
tgt_text.2663: ' Because,' said he, if we continue to sail at the rate we do at present, we shall arrive off the island about the first watch of the night;
tgt_text.2664: and I fear lest, in the darkness, we may strike upon some of the rocks which abound under the sea on that coast:
tgt_text.2665: it is better therefore for us to keep out at sea all night, carrying only so much sail as may suffice to bring us under the island in the morning.'
tgt_text.2666: This was the opinion of the pilot:
tgt_text.2667: however we made land sooner than he expected, and cast anchor at Zacynthus just as the sun rose.“
tgt_text.2668: The inhabitants of the port, which was not far distant from the city, flocked together at our arrival, as to an unusual spectacle.
tgt_text.2669: They admired the construction of our vessel, framed with regard both to size and beauty;
tgt_text.2670: and from thence formed an idea of the skill and industry of the Phoenicians.
tgt_text.2671: Still more did they wonder at our un­ common good fortune in having had so prosperous a pas­ sage, in the midst of winter, and at the setting of the Pleiades."
tgt_text.2672: Almost all the ship's company, while the vessel was being moored, hurried off to the city to buy what things they wanted.
tgt_text.2673: I strolled about in search of a lodging, some­ where on the shore, for the pilot had told me that we should probably winter at Zacynthus:
tgt_text.2674: to remain on board the ship would have been very inconvenient, because of the noisy crew, and our fugitives could not be so well concealed in the city as their situation required."
tgt_text.2675: When I had walked a little way, I saw an old fisherman sitting before his door, and mending his nets.
tgt_text.2677: Can you inform me, my good friend,' said I, ‘ where I can hire a lodging ‘It was broken,' said he, ‘ near yonder promontory, having caught upon a rock.'-‘
tgt_text.2678: This was not what I inquired,' said I;
tgt_text.2679: ' but you would do me a kind office if you will either receive me into your own house, or show me another where I may be taken in.'—‘
tgt_text.2680: It was not I who did it, I warrant you,' said he;
tgt_text.2681: ‘ I was not in the boat;
tgt_text.2682: old ago has not yet so dulled the faculties of Tyrrhenus.
tgt_text.2683: It was the fault of the lubberly boys which occasioned this mishap, who, from ignorance of the reefs, spread their nets in the wrong place.'“
tgt_text.2684: Perceiving now that he was hard of hearing, I bawled out at the top of my voice, ‘ Good day to you!
tgt_text.2685: Can you show us, who are strangers, a place where we may find lodging ?' -‘
tgt_text.2686: The same to you,' answered he.
tgt_text.2688: You may, if you please, lodge with me;
tgt_text.2689: unless, perhaps, you are one of those who require a great many beds and chambers, and have a large number of servants with you.'
tgt_text.2691: I have only two children with nlyself -‘
tgt_text.2692: A very good number,' he replied,‘ for you will find my family consist of only one more.
tgt_text.2693: I have two sons who live witH me;
tgt_text.2694: their elder brothers are married and settled by themselves;
tgt_text.2695: I have, besides, the nurse of my children, for their mother has been some time dead;
tgt_text.2696: wherefore, good sir, do not hesi­ tate, nor doubt that we shall receive gladly one whose first aspect is venerable and .prepossessing.'
tgt_text.2698: and when I returned afterwards with Theagenes and Chariclea, the old fisherman received us with great cor­ diality, and assigned us the warmest and most convenient part of his habitation.
tgt_text.2699: “The beginning of the winter passed hero not unplea­ santly.
tgt_text.2700: We lived together in the day time :
tgt_text.2702: Chariclea slept in one apartment, with the nurse, I in another, with Theagenes, and Tyrrhenus in a third, with his children.
tgt_text.2703: Our table was in* common, and well supplied;
tgt_text.2704: the old man furnished it abundantly with provision from the sea.
tgt_text.2705: We frequently amused our leisure by assisting him in fishing, in which art he was very skilful, and had tackle for it in abundance, and suited for every season.*
tgt_text.2706: The coast was convenient for placing his nets, and abounded with fish, so that most people attributed his success in his occupation to his good fortune alone, which was in part, however, owing to his skill.
tgt_text.2707: Thus, for some time, we lived in peace;
tgt_text.2708: but it is not permitted to the unhappy to be long at ease;
tgt_text.2709: nor could the charms of Chari­ clea, even in this solitude, be exempt from disturbance."
tgt_text.2710: The Tyrian merchant, that victor in the Pythian games, with whom we sailed, was very annoying to me;
tgt_text.2711: he took every opportunity of pressing me with earnestness, as a father, to grant him Chariclea in marriage.
tgt_text.2712: He vaunted his family and his fortune.
tgt_text.2713: He said that the vessel in which we sailed was entirely his property;
tgt_text.2714: and the greatest part of her cargo, which consisted of gold, precious stones, and silk.
tgt_text.2715: He crowned all these, and many other recom­ mendations of himself, with his victory in Greece, which he thought reflected no small lustre upon him.
tgt_text.2716: I objected my present poverty, and that I could never bring myself to dispose of my daughter in a foreign country, and at such a distance from Egypt.
tgt_text.2718: Talk not of poverty,' he would reply;
tgt_text.2719: ‘ I shall esteem the gift of Chariclea's hand more than a portion of a thousand talents.
tgt_text.2720: Wherever she is, I shall look upon that place as my country;
tgt_text.2721: I am ready to change my destined course to Carthage, and sail with you wherever you please.'"
tgt_text.2722: When, alter some time, I saw the Phœnician relax nothing of his importunity, but that he grew more urgent every day in his solicitations, I determined to flatter him with fallacious hopes, lest he should offer some violence to us in the island, and promised I would do everything which he wished when wo arrived in Egypt.
tgt_text.2723: But I had no sooner thus quieted him a little, than a new wave of trouble came rolling in upon me.†“
tgt_text.2724: Old Tyrrhenus accosted me one day as I was wandering in a retired part of the coast.
tgt_text.2725: ‘ My good Calasiris,' said he, ‘ Neptune is my witness, and all the gods, that I regard you as my brother, and your children as my own.
tgt_text.2726: I am come to discover to you a gathering danger winch will occa­ sion you great uneasiness, but which I cannot, with any regard to the laws of hospitality, conceal from one who lodges under my roof, and which it concerns you much to be acquainted with.
tgt_text.2727: A nest of pirates, concealed under the side of yonder promontory, are lying in wait for your Phœ­ nician vessel.
tgt_text.2728: They are continually on the watch for your sailing out of port.
tgt_text.2729: I caution you, therefore, to beware, and to consider what you have to do;
tgt_text.2730: for it is on your account, or rather, as I suspect, on account of your daugh­ ter, that they have conceived this audacious design, which they are but too well prepared for.'.'May the gods reward you,' said I, ‘ for your kind information;
tgt_text.2731: but, my dear Tyrrhenus, how did you obtain your intelligence ?'—'
tgt_text.2732: My trade,' ho auswered, makes me acquainted with these men;
tgt_text.2733: I take fish to them, for which they pay me a better price than others;
tgt_text.2734: and yesterday, as I was taking up lilY nets on the shore, Trachinus, the captain of the pirates, came and asked me if 1 knew when the Phœnicians intended to set sail.
tgt_text.2735: I, suspecting his intent, replied, that indeed I did not exactly know, but I supposed that it would be early in the spring.
tgt_text.2737: Does the fair maiden, who lodges at your house, sail with them ?'—

tgt_text.5843: While he was thus playing in the heat of the noon-day, and their flocks around them were reposing in the shade, Chloe imperceptibly fell asleep.
tgt_text.5844: Daphnis laid down his pipe, and while gazing upon her whole person with insa­ liable eyes, there being no one to inspire him with shame;
tgt_text.5845: he thus murmured, directing his words to her:
tgt_text.5846: —“ What eyes are those, which are now closed in sleep!
tgt_text.5847: what a mouth is that, which breathes so sweetly!
tgt_text.5848: no apples, no thickets, exhale so delicious a scent!
tgt_text.5850: but I fear to kiss her!
tgt_text.5851: a kiss consumes me, and like new honey,- maddens me!
tgt_text.5852: besides, a kiss would wake her!
tgt_text.5853: A plague upon those chirping grasshoppers, their shrill notes will disturb my Chloe!
tgt_text.5854: those vexatious goats, too, are clashing their horns together;
tgt_text.5855: surely the wolves are grown more cowardly than foxes, that they do not come and seize them!
tgt_text.5856: "As he was thus soliloquizing, he was interrupted by a grasshopper, which in springing from a swallow which pur­ sued it, fell into Chloe's bosom.
tgt_text.5857: The swallow was unable to take its prey, but hovered over Chloe's cheek and touched it with its wings.
tgt_text.5859: but seeing the swallow still fluttering near her, and Daphnis laughing at her alarm, her fear vanished, and she rubbed her eyes, which were still disposed to sleep.
tgt_text.5860: The grass­ hopper chirped from her bosom, as if in gratitude for his deliverance.
tgt_text.5861: At the sound Chloe screamed again;
tgt_text.5862: at which Daphnis laughed, and availing himself of the opportunity, put his hand into her bosom and drew the happy chirper from its place, which did not cease its note even when in his hand;
tgt_text.5863: Chloe was pleased at seeing the innocent cause of her alarm, kissed it, and replaced it, still singing, in her bosom.
tgt_text.5864: At this moment they were delighted with listening to a ring-dove in the neighbouring wood, and upon Chloe's inquiring what the bird meant by its note, Daphnis told her the legend, which was commonly current:
tgt_text.5865: —“ There was a maiden, my love, who, like yourself, was beautiful;
tgt_text.5866: like yourself, she tended largo herds of cattle;
tgt_text.5867: and, like yourself, She was in the flower of youth.
tgt_text.5869: —so sweetly, that the herds were delighted with her song, and needed neither the crook nor the goad to manage them ;
tgt_text.5871: and remaining near listened to the maid, as she sat under the shade of the pine crowned with a garland of its leaves, and singing the praises of Pan,* and the nymph Pitys.
tgt_text.5872: A youth, who pastured his herds at a little distance, and who was handsome, and fond as herself of melody, vied with her in singing;
tgt_text.5873: as he was a man, his tones were deeper, but as he was young, they were very sweet.
tgt_text.5874: He sang, and charmed away eight of her best cows to his own pastures.
tgt_text.5875: The maiden was mortified at the loss of her cattle, and at being so much surpassed in song;
tgt_text.5876: and, in her despair, prayed the gods to convert her into a bird before she reached her home.
tgt_text.5877: The gods assented to her prayer, and metamorphosed her into a bird;
tgt_text.5878: under which form, as of old, she frequents the mountains, and delights in warbling.

tgt_text.5882: when some pirates of Tyre, in a light Carian bark,t that they might not appear to be foreigners, touched at that coast and came on shore, armed with coats of mail and swords, and plun­ dered everything which fell in their way.

tgt_text.5886: When the pirates saw this stout and handsome youth, who, they knew, would be a prize of greater value than the plunder of the fields, they took no more trouble about the goats, not did they proceed farther, but carried off the unlucky Daphnis to their vessel, weeping as he was hurried along, at a loss what to do, and calling loudly upon Chloe.

tgt_text.5899: with it I have obtained the prize from many a shepherd and many a herdsman.

tgt_text.5901: and when I am dead, shed a tear over me:
tgt_text.5902: and when you see another tending my flocks, remember Dorco.

tgt_text.5905: The cows began to low at hearing the well-known note, and leaped all at once into the sea.
tgt_text.5906: As they all plunged from the same side, and caused a mighty chasm in the waters the vessel lurched, the waves closed over it, and it sank.
tgt_text.5907: The crew and Daphnis fell into the sea, but they had not equal chances for preser­ vation.
tgt_text.5908: The pirates were encumbered with their swords, scaled breast-plates, and greaves reaching to mid-leg:
tgt_text.5909: whereas Daphnis, who had been feeding his flocks in the plains, had not even his sandals on;
tgt_text.5910: and the weather being still very warm, he was half-naked.
tgt_text.5911: AL swam for a little time, but their armour soon sunk the foreigners to the bottom.
tgt_text.5912: Daphnis easily threw off the garments which remained to encumber him, but, accustomed to swim only in rivers, buoyed himself up with great difficulty:
tgt_text.5913: at length, taught by necessity, he struck forward between two of the cows, grasped a horn of each of them, and was carried along as securely and as easily, as if he had been riding in his own wain.
tgt_text.5914: Oxen, be it observed, are better swimmers than men, or indeed than any animals, except aquatic birds and fish, nor are they in any danger of drowning unless their hoofs become softened by the water.
tgt_text.5915: The fact of many places being still called Ox-fords,* will bear out the truth of my assertion.
tgt_text.5916: Thus was Dapbnis delivered from two perils-from the pirates and from shipwreck, and in a manner beyond all expectation.
tgt_text.5917: When he reached the shore, he found Chloe smiling through her tears:
tgt_text.5918: he fell on her bosom, and in­ quired, what had led her to play that particular tune.
tgt_text.5919: —She related everything which had occurred-her running to Dorco—the habit of his cows—HIS ordering her to pipe that tune, and finally his death, but through a feeling of shame she said nothing of the kiss.
tgt_text.5920: They now determined to pay the last honours to their benefactor;
tgt_text.5921: accordingly they came with the neighbours and relatives of the deceased, and buried him.
tgt_text.5922: They then threw up over his grave a large pile of earth, and planted about it various trees, and suspended over it† the emblems of their calling;
tgt_text.5923: in addition to which they poured libations of milk and of juice expressed from the grapes, and broke many pastoral pipes.
tgt_text.5924: Mournful lowings of the cattle were heard, accompanied with unwonted and disorderly movements, which the shepherds believed to be lamentations and tokens of sorrow on the part of the herd for their departed herdsman.
tgt_text.5925: *After the funeral of Dorco, Chloe led Daphnis to the grotto of the Nymphs, where she washed him;
tgt_text.5926: and then, for the first time in his presence, bathed her own person, fair and radiant with beauty, and needing no bath to set off its comeliness.
tgt_text.5927: Then, after gathering the flowers which the season afforded, they crowned the statues with garlands, and suspended Dorco's pipe as a votive offering to the Nymphs.
tgt_text.5928: Having done this they returned to look for their flocks, which they found lying on the ground neither feeding nor bleating, but looking about, as if waiting in suspense for their re-appearance.
tgt_text.5929: When they came in view of them, and called to them in their usual manner, and sounded their pipes, the sheep got up, and began to feed, while the goats skipped about, and bleated as if exulting at the safety of their herdsman.*
tgt_text.5930: But Daphnis could not attune his soul to joy;
tgt_text.5931: after seeing Chloe naked, and her formerly con­ cealed beauties unveiled, he felt an inward pain as though preyed upon by poison.
tgt_text.5932: His breath went and came as though he were flying from some pursuer;
tgt_text.5933: and then it failed, as though he were exhausted with running.
tgt_text.5934: Chloe had come from the bath with redoubled charms, and the bath was thus more fatal to Daphnis than the ocean.
tgt_text.5935: As for him­ self, he attributed his feelings to being, in fancy, still among the thieves,†—rustic as he was, and as yet ignorant of the thievish tricks of love.
tgt_text.5936: IT was now the middle of autumn :
tgt_text.5937: -the vintage* was at hand, and every one was busy in the fields.
tgt_text.5938: One† pre­ pared the wine-presses, another cleansed the casks, and another twisted the osiers into baskets.
tgt_text.5939: Each had a sepa­ rate employ-in providing short pruning hooks, to cut the grapes;
tgt_text.5940: or a heavy stone, to pound them;
tgt_text.5941: or dry vine branches, previously well bruised, to serve as torches, so that the must might be carried away at night.
tgt_text.5942: Daphnis and Chloe neglected for a time their flocks and mutually assisted one another.
tgt_text.5943: He carried the clusters in baskets, threw them into the wine-presses, trod them, and drew off the wine into casks ;
tgt_text.5944: she prepared their meals for the grape-gatherers, brought old wine for their drink, and plucked off the lowest bunches.
tgt_text.5945: Indeed, all the vines in Lesbos were of lowly growth, and instead of shooting up­ wards, or twining around trees, they spread their branches downwards, which trailed along, like ivy, so close to the ground, that even an infant might reach the fruit.
tgt_text.5946: The women, who, according to the custom at this festival of Bacchus, and birth of the vine, were called from the neighbouring villages to lend their assistance, all cast their eyes upon Daphnis, and exclaimed that he was equal in beauty to Bacchus himself.
tgt_text.5947: One of the most forward of these wenches gave him a kiss, which inflamed Daphnis, but sadly grieved poor Chloe.
tgt_text.5948: On the other hand, the men who-were treading the wine- press indulged in all manner of jests about Chloe, they danced round her as furiously as so many Bacchanals round a Bacchante, and exclaimed that they would gladly become sheep to be fed by her hand.
tgt_text.5949: These compliments delighted Chloe, but tormented poor Daphnis.
tgt_text.5950: Each of them wished the vintage over, that they might return to their usual haunts, and instead of this discordant din might hear the sound of their pipe, and the bleating of their sheep.
tgt_text.5951: In a few days the vines were stript,—the casks were filled,—there was no longer any need of more hands, they therefore drove their flocks to the plain.
tgt_text.5952: In the first place, with sincere delight they went to pay their adoration to the Nymphs, and carried vine-branchés with clusters of grapes on them, as first-fruit offerings from the vintage.
tgt_text.5953: Indeed, they never had hitherto passed by the Grotto without some token of respect, but always saluted them as they passed by with their flocks to their morning pasture, and when they returned in the evening, they paid their adoration, and presented, as an offering, either a flower, or some fruit, or a green leaf, or a libation of milk.
tgt_text.5954: This piety, as we shall see, had in the end its due reward.
tgt_text.5955: At the time we speak of, like young hounds just let loose, they leaped about, they piped, they sang, and wrestled and played with their goats and sheep.
tgt_text.5956: While thus sporting and enjoying themselves, an old man, clothed in a coarse coat of skin, with shoes of undressed leather on his feet, and with a wallet (which, by the by, was a very old one) at his back, came up, seated himself near them, and addressed them as follows :
tgt_text.5957: — "I who now address you, my children, am PHILETAS.
tgt_text.5958: I have often sung the praises of the Nymphs of yonder Grotto—I have often piped in honour of Pan, and have guided my numerous herd by the music of my voice.
tgt_text.5959: I come to acquaint you with what I have seen and heard.
tgt_text.5960: I have a garden* which I cultivate with my own hands, and in which I have always worked, since I became too old to tend my herds.
tgt_text.5961: In it is every production of the different seasons;
tgt_text.5962: in spring it abounds with roses, lilies, hyacinths, and either kind of violets;
tgt_text.5963: in summer with poppies, pears, and apples of every sort;
tgt_text.5964: and now in autumn, with grapes, figs, pomegranates, and green myrtles.
tgt_text.5965: A. variety of birds fly into it every morning, some in search of food, and some to warble in the shade;
tgt_text.5966: for the over­ arching boughs afford thick shade, and three fountains water the cool retreat.
tgt_text.5967: Were it not inclosed with a wall, it might be taken for a natural wood.
tgt_text.5968: As I entered it to- day, about noon, I espied a little boy under my pomegra­ nates and myrtles, some of which he had gathered ;
tgt_text.5969: and was holding them in his hands.
tgt_text.5970: His complexion was white as milk, his hair a bright yellow, and he shone as if he had just been bathing.
tgt_text.5971: He was naked and alone, and amused him­ self with plucking the fruit with as much freedom as if it had been his own garden.
tgt_text.5972: Apprehensive that in his wantonness he would commit more mischief and break my plants, I sprang forward to seize him, but the urchin lightly and easily escaped from me, sometimes running under rose.
tgt_text.5973: trees, and sometimes hiding himself like a young partridge under the poppies."
tgt_text.5974: I have frequently been fatigued with catching my suck.
tgt_text.5975: ing kids, or my new-dropt calves;
tgt_text.5976: but as to this mischievous creature, in perpetual motion, it was utterly impossible to lay hold of him.
tgt_text.5977: Old as I am I was soon weary with the pursuit;
tgt_text.5978: so, leaning on my staff for support, and keeping my eyes on him lest he should escape, I asked him to what neighbour he belonged, and what he meant by gather­ ing what grew in another person's garden.“
tgt_text.5979: He made no reply, but approaching very near me, smiled sweetly in my face, and pelted me with myrtle-berries, and (I know not how) so won upon me, that my anger was appeased.
tgt_text.5980: I intreated him to come close to me, and assured him that he need not be afraid, swearing by the myrtles, by the apples, and by the pomegranates of my garden, that I wished only to give him one kiss,.
tgt_text.5981: for which he should ever afterwards have liberty to gather as much fruit, and to pluck as many flowers as he pleased.“
tgt_text.5982: Upon hearing me thus address him, he burst into a merry laugh, and with a voice sweeter than that of the swallow or the nightingale, or of the swan when grown aged like myself, he replied:
tgt_text.5983: 'I grudge you not a kiss, Philetas, for I have more pleasure in being kissed, than you would have in growing young again;
tgt_text.5984: but consider whether the gift would suit your time of life;
tgt_text.5985: for, old as you are, one kiss would not satisfy you, nor prevent you from running after me, while if even a hawk, an eagle, or any other swifter bird, were to pursue me it would pursue in vain.
tgt_text.5986: I am not the child which I appear to be ;
tgt_text.5987: but I am older than SATURN, ay, older than TIME himself.
tgt_text.5988: I knew you well, Philetas, when you were in the flower of your youth, and when you tended your widely-scattered flock in yonder marsh.
tgt_text.5989: I was near you, when you sat beneath those beech-trees, and were wooing your Amaryllis :
tgt_text.5990: I was close to the maiden, but you could not discern mo.
tgt_text.5991: I gave her to you, and some fine boys, who are now excellent husband­ men and herdsmen, are the pledges of your love.
tgt_text.5992: At this present time I am tending Daphnis and Chloe like a shep­ herd;
tgt_text.5993: and when I have brought them together in the morning, I retire to your garden:
tgt_text.5994: here I disport myself among your flowers and plants, and here I bathe in your fountain.
tgt_text.5995: Through mo it is that your flowers and shrubs are so beauteous, for the waters, which have bathed me, refresh them.
tgt_text.5996: Look now, if any of your plants be broken down!—see, if any of your fruit be plucked !-examine whether the stalk of any flower be crushed -or the clearness of any one of your fountains be disturbed !
tgt_text.5997: and rejoice that you alone, in your old age, have bad the privilege of beholding the boy who is now before you.'
tgt_text.5998: With these words he sprang like the youngling of a nightingale among the myrtles, and climbing from bough to bough ascended through the foliage to the summit of the tree.
tgt_text.5999: I observed wings upon his shoulders, and between them a tiny bow,.
tgt_text.6001: but in a moment I could neither see him nor them.
tgt_text.6002: Unless I have grown grey in vain, unless I have got into my dotage in growing old, you may rely on me, when I assure you, that you are consecrate to LOVE, and . that you are under his peculiar care.
tgt_text.6003: "Daphnis and Choe were delighted, but they regarded what they had heard as an amusing story rather than a sober fact;
tgt_text.6004: and inquired ot Philetas who and what this LOVE could be ?
tgt_text.6005: whether he were a boy or a bird ?
tgt_text.6006: and of what powers he was possessed ? “
tgt_text.6007: My young friends," said Philetas, “ he is a god, young, beautiful, and ever on the wing.
tgt_text.6008: He rejoices, therefore, in the company of youth, ho is ever in search of beauty, and adds wings to the souls of those he favours.*
tgt_text.6009: He has power far beyond that of Jove himself.
tgt_text.6010: He commands the elements, he rules the stars, and even the gods themselves, who are otherwise his equals;
tgt_text.6011: t your power over your flocks is nothing compared to his.
tgt_text.6012: All these flowers are the works of love:
tgt_text.6013: these plants arc effects produced by him.
tgt_text.6014: Through him these rivers flow, and these zephyrs breathe.
tgt_text.6015: I have seen a bull smitten by his power, who bellowed as though breeze-stung.
tgt_text.6017: I have seen the goat enamoured of the female, and following her everywhere.
tgt_text.6018: I myself was once young, I felt his influence, I loved Ama­ rillis.
tgt_text.6019: I thought not of my food, I cared not for my drink;
tgt_text.6020: I could take no rest, for sleep was banished from my eye­ lids.
tgt_text.6021: My soul was sad—my heart beat quick—my limbs felt a deadly chill.
tgt_text.6022: Now I cried aloud, as if I had been beaten;
tgt_text.6023: now I was as silent as if I were dead;
tgt_text.6024: and now I plunged into the rivers, as if to extinguish the flame which consumed me.
tgt_text.6025: I invoked Pan to assist me, inasmuch as he had known what it was to love his Pitys.
tgt_text.6026: I poured forth praises to the Nymph Echo for repeating the name of my Amaryllis:
tgt_text.6027: in anger I broke my pipe because it could soothe my herds, but could not prevail over Amaryllis;
tgt_text.6028: for there is no mighty magic against love;
tgt_text.6029: no medicine, whether in food or drink:
tgt_text.6030: nothing, in short, save kisses - and em­ braces, and the closest union of the naked body.
tgt_text.6031: "Philetas, having given them this information, bade them farewell;
tgt_text.6032: but before permitting him to depart, they presented him with a cheese, and a kid with newly budding horns.
tgt_text.6033: Daphnis and Chloe, left to themselves, mused in silence upon the name of Love, which they had now beard for the first time.
tgt_text.6034: Sorrow seemed to have stupified them, till at night, as they returned home, they began to compare their own sensations with what they had heard from Philetas.‘
tgt_text.6035: According to Philetas, lovers are sad—so are we;
tgt_text.6036: they neglect their calling-so do we;
tgt_text.6037: they cannot sleep-no more can we.
tgt_text.6038: A fire appears to burn within them­ we feel this fire;
tgt_text.6039: they long for the sight of one another —we, too, are always wishing for the day to dawn.
tgt_text.6040: Our disorder must be love, and we have loved each other with­ out being aware of it.
tgt_text.6041: If this be not love, and if wo be not mutually lovers, why are we thus sad?
tgt_text.6042: why do we so eagerly seek each other P All that Philetas has told us is true.
tgt_text.6043: The boy, whom he saw in the garden, is the same who appeared to our parents in the dream, and commanded that we should follow the pastoral life.
tgt_text.6044: How is it possible to catch the urchin ?
tgt_text.6045: He is little and will escape from us.
tgt_text.6046: At the same time, who can escape from him He has wings, and will pursue us.
