tgt_text.6050: we shall feel it very cold, but we will bear what Philetas has borne before us.
tgt_text.6051: Thus were their thoughts employed during the night.
tgt_text.6052: The next morning, after driving their flocks to pasture, they for the first time kissed each other upon meeting, and afterwards mutually embraced.
tgt_text.6053: The third remedy they were afraid of;
tgt_text.6054: the lying naked upon the grass appeared too bold a step for a maiden, Day, even for a youthful goatherd.
tgt_text.6055: Again, therefore, they passed a sleepless night, calling to mind what they had done, regretting what they had omitted. " .
tgt_text.6056: We kissed," said they, "and are none the better;
tgt_text.6057: we embraced, and have found no relief.
tgt_text.6058: This lying side by side must needs be the sole remedy for love;
tgt_text.6059: assuredly it will prove more effica­ cious than the kiss and the embrace."
tgt_text.6060: As might have been expected, their dreams were akin to their daily thoughts.
tgt_text.6061: In sleep they kissed and they embraced;
tgt_text.6062: in sleep they did that which they had omitted to do during the day.
tgt_text.6063: Next morning they arose more than ever inflamed with passion, and hissed* along their flocks, all the while in anticipation of the kiss.
tgt_text.6064: They came in sight of one another, their faces mutually beaming with delight.
tgt_text.6065: Again there was repeated the kiss and the embrace;
tgt_text.6066: the remaining remedy was still untried, Daphnis being unwilling to propose it, and Chloe feeling the like hesitation.
tgt_text.6068: They were sitting beside each other upon the trunk of a tree:
tgt_text.6069: having once tasted the luxury of a kiss, they were insatiable of its delight;
tgt_text.6070: they entwined one another in their arms, and so drew their bodies into closer contact.
tgt_text.6071: Daphnis, in the course of this embrace, straining Chloo more tightly to his bosom, she falls upon her side, and be falls with her, and thus acting out the image of their dreams, they long lay locked in each other's arms.
tgt_text.6072: Their innocence knew nothing beyond this;
tgt_text.6073: they imagined that love had nothing farther to bestow;
tgt_text.6074: so after fruitlessly passing the greater portion of the day in this manner, they separated, and drove home their flocks, loathing the approach of night.
tgt_text.6075: They might, perhaps, on a future occasion have become greater adepts in the mysteries of love, had not the fol­ lowing circumstance spread tumult and confusion through­ out their neighbourhood.
tgt_text.6076: Some rich young men of Methymnn, who had formed a pleasure party for passing the vintage-season out of town, launched a small vessel, employing their servants as rowers, and shaped their course towards the fields of Mitylene, which lie near the sea-coast.
tgt_text.6077: They knew that there was an excellent harbour for them, with every thing adapted for their accommodation, as the shore was adorned with handsome houses, with baths, with gardens, and with groves, some of which were the productions of nature, and some of art.
tgt_text.6078: Here the party arrived, and drew their boat into a safe place, after which they committed no acts of mischief, but amused themselves in various ways, with rod and line angling for rock-fish, which were found under the different promontories, or hunting the hares, which, terrified by the noise of the grape gatherers, had fled towards the shore, and capturing them by means of dogs and nets.
tgt_text.6079: Part of their amusement also was to set snares for birds:
tgt_text.6080: many wild ducks, wild geese and bustards were caught, so that their sport supplied their table in a great measure;
tgt_text.6081: and whatever addition they wanted was easily procured from the labourers in the fields, who were paid more than its worth for everything which they supplied.
tgt_text.6082: Their chief inconvenience was want of bread and wine, and a good lodging at night;
tgt_text.6083: for as it was late in the autumn, they did not think it safe to sleep on board their boat, but in appre­ hension of storms, usual at this season, were ,,'ont to draw it up on shore.
tgt_text.6084: It so happened that a countryman had broken the old rope to which the stone was suspended for crushing his grapes after they had been trodden in the wine-press, and being in want of another to supply its place, had come clandestinely down to the sea-shore, and taking the cable from the boat, which was left without any one to watch it, had quietly conveyed it home to supply his need.
tgt_text.6085: The young Methymnæans, in the morning, made inquiries after their rope;
tgt_text.6086: but as no one confessed the theft, after venting their reproaches on this breach of hospitality, they launched their boat, and left that part of the coast.
tgt_text.6087: After sailing rather more than a league, they landed on the estate where Daphnis and Chloe dwelt.
tgt_text.6088: It appeared to them to be a good country for hare-hunting.
tgt_text.6089: Having no rope to serve as a cable, they twisted some vine-branches as a substi.
tgt_text.6090: tute, and tied the head of their boat to the shore:
tgt_text.6091: then let loose the dogs to scent about in the places most likely for game, and fixed their nets.
tgt_text.6092: The cry of the hounds, running hither and thither, frightened the goats, which fled from the mountains down to the sea-shore, where some of the boldest of the flock, finding no food upon the coast, approached the boat and gnawed the branches which were fastened as a cable.
tgt_text.6093: At the same moment a swell set in, owing to the breezes blowing from the mountains.
tgt_text.6094: The motion of the waves began to carry off the boat, and, at length, bore it out to sea.
tgt_text.6096: some of them ran in great haste down to the shore:
tgt_text.6097: others hastened to call the dogs together:
tgt_text.6098: and all of them cried out for assistance, in hopes of assembling the labourers from the neighbouring fields.
tgt_text.6099: It was all of no avail, for the wind increased, and the boat was driven down the current.
tgt_text.6100: When the Methym­ næans found themselves thus deprived of it, and of the con­ siderable property which it contained, they inquired for the goat-herd, and finding him to be Daphnis, they beat him severely and stripped him.
tgt_text.6101: One of them took a dog-leash, and bending Daphnis’ arms behind his back, was preparing to bind him.
tgt_text.6102: Poor Daphnis, smarting with his beating, roared out for assistance :
tgt_text.6103: he called upon all his neighbours, but upon Lamon and Dryas in particular.
tgt_text.6104: The old men took his part stoutly:
tgt_text.6105: the toils of husbandry had made them hard handed;
tgt_text.6106: they demanded that an inquiry should be made agreeably to the rules of justice.
tgt_text.6107: The neighbours, who had now reached the spot, backed them in their demand, and appointed Phile­ tas umpire in the business.
tgt_text.6108: He was the oldest man present, and was celebrated among the villagers for the equity of his decisions.
tgt_text.6109: The charge of the Methymnæans was made plainly and with conciseness suitable to the rustic judge before whom they pleaded.
tgt_text.6110: “ We came here," said they, “ to hunt, and fastened our boat to the shore with some vine-branches, while we roamed about with our dogs in search of game.
tgt_text.6111: In the meantime, this young man’s goats came down to the coast and ate the fastening of our boat, which has proved the loss of it.
tgt_text.6112: You yourself, saw it driven out to sea, and what valuables think you it had on board ?
tgt_text.6113: Why, store of clothes and of dog-gear, and of money—money enough to have purchased all these fields around us.
tgt_text.6114: In return for what we have lost, we have surely a right to carry off this heedless goatherd, who, sailor-fashion, chooses to pasture his goats on the sea- coast.
tgt_text.6116: Daphnis was in sore plight from the blows which he had received ;
tgt_text.6117: but seeing Chloe among the crowd, he rose superior to his pain, and spoke as follows“I am, and always have been very careful of my herds.
tgt_text.6118: What neighbour can say that a goat of mine ever browsed upon his garden, or devoured any of his sprouting vines ?
tgt_text.6119: It is these sportsmen who are themselves to blame, for hav­ ing dogs so badly broken as to run wildly about making such a barking, and like so many wolves driving my sheep from hill and dale down to the sea.
tgt_text.6120: The poor brutes eat the vine branches;
tgt_text.6121: no wonder, for they could find no grass, nor shrubs, nor thyme upon the sands.
tgt_text.6122: The sea and the winds destroyed the boat;
tgt_text.6123: let the storm bear the blame and not my goats.
tgt_text.6124: They say, that they had left their clothes and money on board:
tgt_text.6125: —who, in his senses, can believe that a boat freighted with so much wealth, was intrusted to a vine branch for its cable ?
tgt_text.6126: ”Daphnis said no more, but burst into tears, which moved all his countrymen with compassion.
tgt_text.6127: Philetas, the judge, swore by Pan and the Nymphs, that neither Daphnis nor his goats were in fault;
tgt_text.6128: that only the sea and the winds could be accused, and that they were not under his jurisdic­ tion.
tgt_text.6129: This decision had no effect on the Methymnæans, who flew into a rage, and seizing Daphnis, were preparing to bind him.
tgt_text.6130: The villagers irritated at such behaviour, full upon them as thick as starlings or rooks, and rescued Daph­ nis, who now began to fight in his own defence.
tgt_text.6131: In a very short time the Mitylenæans, by dint of their clubs, put the strangers to flight, and did not desist from the pursuit, till they had driven them into a different quarter of the island.
tgt_text.6132: While they were engaged in the pursuit, Chloe led Dapin­ nis gently by the hand to the grotto of the Nymphs ;
tgt_text.6133: their she washed the blood from his face and nostrils, and taking a slice of bread and cheese from her scrip, gave it him to eat.
tgt_text.6134: After she had thus refreshed him, she impressed a honeyed kiss with her tender lips.
tgt_text.6135: So near was Daphnis getting into serious trouble;
tgt_text.6136: but the affair did not end here.
tgt_text.6137: The Methymnæans reached their own city with much pain and difficulty;
tgt_text.6138: for instead of sail­ ing they bad to travel on foot, and instead of every luxury, and convenience, they had nothing but bruises and wounds for their comfort.
tgt_text.6139: Immediately upon their arrival at home, they called an assembly of their fellow townsmen, and in­ treated them to take up arms to avenge their cause, which they represented in their own way, altogether concealing the real truth of the matter, for fear of being laughed at for having been so soundly beaten by a few shepherds.
tgt_text.6140: They accused the people of Mitylene of having seized their boat, as if it belonged to an enemy, and of plundering it of all its contents.
tgt_text.6141: Their wounds, which they exhibited, gained them belief among their countrymen, who resolved to avenge the cause of the young men, and more particularly as they belonged to the first families in the place.
tgt_text.6142: Accord­ ingly they resolved to begin the war without the usual forms of proclamation, and ordered their naval commander to launch ten vessels immediately, and ravage the coasts of the enemy.
tgt_text.6143: As the winter was coming on they did not think it safe to hazard a larger fleet.
tgt_text.6144: Early the very next day he put to sea;
tgt_text.6145: and employing his soldiers as rowers, steered his course to the shores of Mity­ lene.
tgt_text.6146: Here he seized numbers of cattle, a great quantity of corn and wine, (the vintage being lately ended,) together with the labourers who were still at work there.
tgt_text.6147: Thus plundering as they went, they landed at last on the estate where Daphnis and Chloe resided, and carried off whatever came to hand.
tgt_text.6148: Daphnis was not then tending his goats, but had gone to the wood, to cut green branches for the winter fodder of his kids.
tgt_text.6149: Looking down from the woods, he saw these ravages;
tgt_text.6150: and immediately hid himself in the hollow of a decayed beech tree.
tgt_text.6151: Chloe happened to be with the flocks;
tgt_text.6152: she fled in affright to the grotto of the Nymphs:
tgt_text.6154: Here she intreated them, if they had any respect to the deities of the place, to spare her and her flocks;
tgt_text.6155: but her prayers were of no avail:
tgt_text.6156: for the ravagers, after offering many insults to the statues of the goddesses, drove off the flocks, and hurried Chloe along with them, as if she had been one of her own goats or sheep, striking her ever and anon with vine twigs.
tgt_text.6157: Their vessels being now filled with plunder of all kinds, the Methymnæans thought it advisable not to prosecute their voyage farther, but to return home, more especially as they were apprehensive of the winter storms, and of an attack from the inhabitants.
tgt_text.6159: but, as there was no wind, they had to labour at their oars.
tgt_text.6160: Daphnis, (when all was quiet) came down to the plain, the usual place for pasturing their flocks, but not a goat, nor a sheep was to be seen, nor was Chloe herself there:
tgt_text.6161: when he saw the whole place deserted, and found Chloe's pipe thrown upon the ground, he burst into loud and bitter lamentations :
tgt_text.6162: -he ran to the beech tree, which bad been their usual seat, and then to the ocean, to try if he could descry her, he searched for her in the grotto, whither she had fled, and whence she had been dragged away.
tgt_text.6163: Here, at last, he threw himself on the ground in despair, and ex­ claimed against the Nymphs, as the deserters of his Chloe."
tgt_text.6164: Chloe has been torn away from you, yo Nymphs, and yet ye could endure to see it!
tgt_text.6165: she who has woven so many garlands for you, who has poured so many libations of new milk to you, and whose pipe is here suspended as an offering to you !
tgt_text.6166: Never did a wolf carry off a single goat of mine, but marauders have now carried away all my flock, and their mistress with them.
tgt_text.6167: —My goats will be flayed, my sheep will be sacrificed, and my Chloe will henceforth be confined within a city !
tgt_text.6168: how shall I venture to return to my father and mother without my goats, and without my Chloe ?— I, who shall appear a deserter of my charge!
tgt_text.6169: I have no more flocks to tend, so here will I lie, till death take me, or the enemy again lay hold of me.
tgt_text.6171: my Chloe, do you share in my sufferings ?-do you still remember these plains, these Nymphs and me ;
tgt_text.6172: or are you consoled by having the sheep and goats for your companions in captivity?
tgt_text.6173: "Thus did Daphnis vent his grief, till weary with weeping and lamenting he fell into a deep sleep.
tgt_text.6174: While slumbering, the three Nymphs appeared to stand before him;
tgt_text.6175: they wero tall and beautiful, half-naked and without sandals;
tgt_text.6176: their hair flowed loose over their shoulders, and indeed in every respect they resembled their statues in the grotto.
tgt_text.6177: At first they shewed signs of commiseration for Daphnis, and, presently, the eldest of them addressed him in these con­ solatory words:
tgt_text.6179: Chloe is an object of deeper anxiety to us, than she is even to yourself.
tgt_text.6180: We had compassion on her when she was an infant;
tgt_text.6181: when she was exposed in this grot, we adopted her and bred her up.
tgt_text.6182: She is not Lamon's daughter, nor do Lamon's fields or herds in any part belong to her.
tgt_text.6183: We have at this time been pro­ viding for her safety, so that she shall not be taken to Methymne as a slave, nor be numbered among the spoils.
tgt_text.6184: We have intreated Pan, (whose statue stands beneath yonder pine, and whom you have never honoured even with a bunch of flowers) to come forward as Chloe's champion, for he is more used to warfare than we are, and has often quitted his rural groves to join in the din of battle.
tgt_text.6185: He is on Chloe's side, and he will be found no despicable enemy by the Methymnæans.
tgt_text.6186: Be not uneasy then, nor perplex yourself;
tgt_text.6187: arise, shew yourself to Lamon and Myrtale, who have thrown themselves on the earth in despair, under the idea that you too are carried off by the enemy.
tgt_text.6188: To- morrow Chloe and her flocks shall return, when you shall tend them together, and together shall play upon your pipe.
tgt_text.6189: —Leave your future fates to the care of LOVE.
tgt_text.6190: ItAfter these words and vision in his dream, Daphnis sprang up, and, while his eyes wero filled with tears, partly of grief and partly of joy, he paid his adorations to the statues of the Nymphs, and vowed, that upon Chloe’s safe return he would sacrifice a she-goat (the best of his herd) to the protecting goddesses.
tgt_text.6191: Then he hastened to the pine, beneath whose shade stood the statue of Pan.
tgt_text.6192: The legs of the rural god were those of the goat, and he had a homed forehead;
tgt_text.6193: in one hand he held a pipe, with the other he grasped a goat, which was in the attitude of bounding.
tgt_text.6194: Daphnis adored his statue likewise, prayed in behalf of Chloe, and vowed to sacrifice a he-goat for her safety.
tgt_text.6195: Scarcely could he cease from his tears and in­ treaties by sun-set, when taking up the green fodder which he bad beep cutting, he returned to his home, where his presence dispelled Lamon’s grief and filled him with joy.
tgt_text.6196: After taking some refreshment he retired to rest;
tgt_text.6197: but his sleep was not even then without tears.
tgt_text.6198: In his slumbers he poured forth prayers to the Nymphs to bless him with another vision, and sighed for the return of day, when his Chloe was to be restored.
tgt_text.6199: -Of all nights this appeared to him the longest.
tgt_text.6200: -During its continuance the following events took place
tgt_text.6201: When the Methymnæan commander had rowed somewhat more than a mile, lie wished to afford his men some rest, wearied as they were with their past exertions.
tgt_text.6202: At length be espied a promontory, which projected into the sea in a semicircular form, affording a harbour more calm and secure than even a regular port.
tgt_text.6203: Here he anchored his fleet, keep­ ing his vessels at a distance from the shore, that they might not be exposed to any attack from the inhabitants, while his men indulged themselves at their ease and in all security.
tgt_text.6204: The crews having plenty of all manner of provision among their plunder, eat and drank and gave themselves up to joy, as if they had been celebrating a festival for victory.
tgt_text.6206: and their merriment was being prolonged to night, when suddenly all the earth appeared in a blaze;
tgt_text.6207: and the dash of oars was heard, as if a mighty fleet were approaching.*
tgt_text.6208: They called upon their commander to arm himself:
tgt_text.6210: some fancied that they were wounded;
tgt_text.6211: others that they saw the bodies of the slain before their eyes.
tgt_text.6212: It appeared like a night engagement against an invisible enemy.
tgt_text.6213: A day of greater terror succeeded to the darkness.
tgt_text.6214: The goats belonging to Daphnis, appeared with branches full of ivy berries on their horns:
tgt_text.6215: the rams and ewes, which bad been taken with Chloe, instead of bleating, howled like wolves.
tgt_text.6216: Their mistress was seen to have a garland of pine- leaves round her head.
tgt_text.6217: The sea also had its marvels.
tgt_text.6218: The anchors stuck fast in the mud, and could not be drawn up:
tgt_text.6219: when the men dipped their oars in order to row, they were shattered in pieces.
tgt_text.6220: The dolphins leaped from the sea, and with their tails broke the planks of the vessels.
tgt_text.6221: From the top of the rock behind the promontory the sound of a pipe was heard:
tgt_text.6222: but it did not, like the pipe, delight the ear with dulcet sounds, but terrified like the harsh blast of a trumpet.
tgt_text.6223: The men of Methymna were confounded:
tgt_text.6224: they seized their arms, and called out to their enemies who were invisible;
tgt_text.6225: they prayed for tho return of night, which might bring a truce to their terrors.
tgt_text.6226: To all those who were capable of reflection, it was evident, that these phantasms and sounds proceeded from Pan, who must have conceived some cause of indignation against them:
tgt_text.6227: but what the cause could be, they were at a loss to conjec­ ture, for they had not plundered any thing which was sacred to the god.
tgt_text.6228: About the middle of the day their commander (not without the intervention of the god) fell into a deep sleep, when Pan appeared to him and addressed him thus:
tgt_text.6229: " 0 most abandoned, most impious of men, to what lengths has your madness driven you!
tgt_text.6230: The fields, which are dear to me, ye have filled with the tumults of war:
tgt_text.6231: the herds and the flocks, which were my peculiar care, ye have taken as plunder.
tgt_text.6232: Ye have dragged a virgin from the altar, whom Cupid had reserved in order to adorn a Tale of Love.
tgt_text.6233: Ye regarded not the Nymphs, who beheld your deeds, nor even me the mighty Pau.
tgt_text.6234: Never shall ye reach Methymna, sailing with these spoils, nor shall yourselves escape the terrors of the pipe which has thus confounded you.
tgt_text.6235: Unless ve immediately give back Chloe to the Nymphs, and restore her goats and sheep, I will submerge you and ye shall become food for fishes.
tgt_text.6236: Bestir yourselves, therefore, land both her and them, I will guide your course by sea, and her's by land."ryaxis (for such was the commander's name) awoke from his dream, and immediately ordered the captain of every vessel to search among his prisoners for Chloe.
tgt_text.6237: They soon found her, for she was sitting still crowned with pine-leaves, and brought her before him.
tgt_text.6238: Bryaxis regarded the orna­ ment on her head as a proof and confirmation of what he had seen in the vision, and without delay took her on board his own vessel,.
tgt_text.6239: and conveyed her safe to the shore.
tgt_text.6240: No sooner had she landed than the sound of the pipe was again heard from the rock:
tgt_text.6241: but it was no longer dreadful like the blast of the war trumpet:
tgt_text.6242: on the contrary it was sweet and pastoral in tone, as when the shepherd is leading out his flock to feed.
tgt_text.6243: The sheep ran down the gangway,t without their horny hoofs slipping.
tgt_text.6244: The goats, used to steep places, proceeded still more venturesomely.
tgt_text.6245: Upon reaching the shore the flocks formed themselves in a ring around Chloe, like a company of dancers, skipping and bleating and exhibiting every symptom of joy;
tgt_text.6246: while the sheep and goats and oxen belonging to the other shepherds remained quiet in the holds of the vessels, as if knowing that the pipe, which sounded, was not intended to summon them.
tgt_text.6247: While every one was struck with astonishment, and celebrated the power of Pan, still stranger sights appeared both by sea and land.
tgt_text.6248: Before the Trews had time to heave their anchors, the ships of themselves began to make sail, and a dolphin, which leaped and played on the waves, swam before the admiral's ship as guide.
tgt_text.6249: On the other hand Chloe's goats and sheep were led by most ravishing music of the pipe, which con­ tinued its notes, though the player was invisible:
tgt_text.6250: sheep and goats continued to graze and pace gently onward listening with delight to the melody.
tgt_text.6251: It was the time of evening-pasture, when Daphnis from the summit of a rock espied his Chloe and her flocks.
tgt_text.6254: he shouted in rapture, and hurrying down into the plain threw himself into Chloe's arms, fainted, and fell to the ground.
tgt_text.6255: The kisses and soothing embraces of the maiden with some difficulty restored him to his senses, after which he proceeded to their favourite beech-tree, under the shade of which he Fiat down, and inquired how Chloe had escaped from so many enemies.
tgt_text.6256: Site related everything which had happened-the appearance of the ivy around the goats' horns-the wolfish howling of the sheep-the pine garland encircling her own temples—the blaze of fire on the land—the unwonted noise at sea—the two discordant notes of the pipe-that of war and that of peace-the terrors of the night-and lastly, how the melody guided her hither, though fields and over plains to which she was a stranger.
tgt_text.6257: Upon hearing this, Daphnis recognized the vision of the Nymphs, and the influence of Pan, and in his turn, he gave Chloe an account of all which he had seen and heard.
tgt_text.6258: He informed her how when ready to destroy himself, he had been preserved through the intervention of the Nymphs.
tgt_text.6259: He then sent Chloe to summon Dryas and Lamon with their servants and to desire them to bring every requisite for a sacrifice, while he in the mean time took the choicest of his she-goats, crowned it with ivy (just as it had appeared to the enemy on board of ship) poured milk between its horns, and sacrificed it to the Nymphs.
tgt_text.6260: Then he hung it up and flayed it, and suspended its skin as an offering to them.
tgt_text.6261: Chloe now arrived with Lamon and the servants.
tgt_text.6262: A fire was immediately kindled, upon which part of the goat's flesh was boiled and part of it roasted.
tgt_text.6263: Daphnis offered the first portions to the Nymphs, and poured out to them a libation of new must;
tgt_text.6264: he then piled some leaves into the form of couches, reclined at his ease upon one of them, and gave himself up to good cheer and mirth :
tgt_text.6265: but at the same time kept a watchful eye on his sheep for fear a wolf should effect what the enemy had been foiled in doing.
tgt_text.6266: After this the party sang the praises of the Nymphs in songs, which had been indited by the shepherds of by-gone days.
tgt_text.6267: They slept in the field that night, and in the morning remembered Pan.
tgt_text.6268: The leader of the goats was selected from the herd;
tgt_text.6269: a chaplet of pine-leaves was bound round his horns, and he was led to the statue, which stood beneath the pine;
tgt_text.6270: when after pouring over him a libation of wine*, carefully avoid­ ing all ominous expressions, the victim was slain, suspended, and flayed.
tgt_text.6271: The flesh, part of which was roasted and part boiled, was spread out upon some dry leaves in the meadow.
tgt_text.6272: The skin with the horns was hung up on the tree hard by the statue of the god—a pastoral offering to a pastoral deity.
tgt_text.6273: A first portion also of the flesh was offered, and libations poured to him from the largest goblet.
tgt_text.6276: Having discharged their religious rites, they were reclining on the grass and feasting, when Philetas the herdsman accidentally came by, bringing with him some garlands, and vine-branches, laden with their clusters, as offerings to Pan.
tgt_text.6277: Tityrus, his youngest son, a golden- haired, blue-eyed, fair and sportive boy followed him.
tgt_text.6278: At the sight of Philetas, Daphnis and Chloe sprang from their grassy couch, assisted in crowning Pan, and in suspending the clusters to the tree, and then made Philetas seat himself by them, and join in their carousal.
tgt_text.6279: Very soon, as old men do when their clay is moistened,.
tgt_text.6280: they began to talk of their youthful adventures, of the flocks which they had fed, of incursions of marauders, which they had escaped in the days when they were young.
tgt_text.6281: One prided himself on having slain a wolf:
tgt_text.6282: another boasted, that in piping he was second to Pan alone.
tgt_text.6284: Daphnis and Chloe used urgent entreaties that he would teach them the art, and that he would play on the pipe at the festival of that deity, who delights in its melody.
tgt_text.6285: The old man complained that nge had shortened his powers of breath, but complied with their request, and took up the pipe of Daphnis.
tgt_text.6286: It was a pipe too small to do justice to so great an art;
tgt_text.6287: being suited only for a boy.
tgt_text.6288: Accordingly he despatched Tityrus to bring his own pipe from the cot­ tage, which was rather more than a mile off.
tgt_text.6289: The bov threw aside his cloak,† and darted off like a young fawn.
tgt_text.6290: tarn on, in the mean time, promised to amuse them with the legend of the Syrinx,‡ (or pipe) which he had heard from a Sicilian shepherd, who received a he-goat and a pipe as the price of his song.it
tgt_text.6291: This pipe was not formerly what it is now, an instru­ ment of music it was once a maiden of beautiful form, and melodious voice.
tgt_text.6292: She fed her flocks, she sported with the Nymphs, and the sound of her voice was sweet as it is now.
tgt_text.6293: Pan beheld the maiden feeding her flocks, disporting herself, and singing.
tgt_text.6294: He approached her, and endeavoured to win her to his will, promising her as an enticement that all her she-goats should bear two kids at a birth.
tgt_text.6295: The maiden laughed at his suit, and replied that she would never think of accepting as a lover, one who was neither man nor goat, but a compound half of each.
tgt_text.6297: the maiden fled from him, and when weary with running, hid herself among the reeds of a lake and disappeared.
tgt_text.6298: Her pursuer in a rage cut the reeds, but finding no damsel there, and perceiving what had taken place, he in memory of her formed this instrument .
tgt_text.6299: Compacting with wax unequal reeds in order to shew how the course of their love had not run smooth..-Thus she, who was once a beauteous maiden, is now a musical pipe:
tgt_text.6302: While Philctas was commending Lamon’s legend, which, he said, was more pleasing than any song, Tityrus appeared with his father's pipe, a large instrument formed of the largest reeds, and ornamented with brass over the junctures of the wax.
tgt_text.6303: A person might have imagined it to be the very pipe whose reeds had been first united by Pan.
tgt_text.6304: Philetas rose up, placed himself upon a seat in an erect posture, and began to try whether the reeds were in good order:
tgt_text.6305: he found the air pass through them freely, and then with as much energy as if he had been in the prime of youth, he blew a note so vigorous and full, that it appeared like a band of pipers playing in concert.
tgt_text.6306: By degrees he moderated the vehemence of his tones, and turned them into a softer strain.
tgt_text.6307: Ho ran through all the variations of pastoral melody;
tgt_text.6308: he played the tune, which the oxen obey, that which attracts the goats, that in which the sheep delight.
tgt_text.6309: The notes for the sheep were sweet, those for the oxen deep, those for the goats were shrill.
tgt_text.6310: In short, his single pipe could express the tones of every pipe which is played upon.
tgt_text.6311: Those present lay listening in silent delight;
tgt_text.6312: when Dryas rose up, and desired Philetas to strike up the Bacchanalian tune.
tgt_text.6313: Philetas obeyed, and Dryas began t the VINTAGE­ DANCE, in which he represented the plucking of the grapes, the carrying of the baskets,—the treading of the clusters, the filling of the casks, and the drinking of the new-made wine.
tgt_text.6314: All this Dryas imitated so closely and admirably in his pantomimic dance, that the spectator might fancy the wines, the wine-press, and the casks to be actually before him, and that Dryas was drinking in reality.
tgt_text.6315: Each of the three old men had now severally distinguished himself.

tgt_text.6347: WHEN the Inhabitants of Mitylene heard or the descent made by the ten vessels, and had been informed by some coming from the spot of the plunder which had been carried off, they were of opinion that such an injury on the part of the Methymnœans was insufferable, and immediately raised a force of three thousand infantry and five hundred cavalry, which they put under the command of Hippasus with orders, that he should lead his men by land, and not embark them on board of ship, as a voyage in the winter season would be dangerous.
tgt_text.6348: The general began his march, but he did not lay waste the country of the enemy, nor did he plunder the possessions of the husbandman, or of the shepherd, thinking such petty warfare suitable to a captain of a banditti, rather than to the leader of an army.

tgt_text.6358: Winter, however, was more formidable to Daphnis and Chloe, than war had been.

tgt_text.6365: But Daphnis and Chloe cherished in their memory the pleasures, of which they were now deprived,—their kisses, their em­ braces, and their happy meals together.

tgt_text.7504: all these they maintain came originally from Tyre, their inventor being a Tyrian.
tgt_text.7505: A certain hospitable neatherd (resembling the Athenian Icarius, who is the subject of a very similar story) gave occasion to the legend which I am about to relate.
tgt_text.7506: Bacchus happened to come to the cottage of this countryman, who set before him whatsoever the earth and the labours of his oxen had produced.
tgt_text.7507: Wine, as I observed, was then unknown, like the oxen, therefore, their beverage was water.
tgt_text.7508: Bacchus thanked him for his friendly treatment and pre­ sented to him a "loving cup," t which was filled with wine.
tgt_text.7509: Having taken a hearty draught, and becoming very jovial from its effects, he said :
tgt_text.7511: Whence, stranger, did you pro­ cure this purple water, this delicious blood ?
tgt_text.7512: It is quite different from that which flows along the ground;
tgt_text.7513: for that descends into the vitals, and affords cold comfort at the best;
tgt_text.7514: whereas this, even before entering the mouth, rejoices the nostrils, and though cold to the touch, leaps down into the stomach and begets a pleasurable warmth.” ‡
tgt_text.7515: To this Bacchus replied, " This is the water of an autumnal fruit, this is the blood of the grape,”§ and so saying, he conducted the neatherd to a vine, and squeezing a bunch of grapes said, “ here is the water, and this is the fountain from whence it flows.”
tgt_text.7516: Such is the account which the Tvrians give as to the origin of wine.
tgt_text.7517: It was, as I before said, the festival of this deity which was being celebrated.
tgt_text.7518: My father anxious to do everything handsomely, had made grand preparations for the supper, and there was set in honor of the go , a magnificent goblet of crystal,* in the beauty of its workmanship second only to that of the Chian Glaucus.t
tgt_text.7519: Vines seemingly growing from within encircled it, and their clusters hung down all around ;
tgt_text.7520: as long as the goblet remained empty each grape appeared unripe and green;
tgt_text.7521: but no sooner was the wine poured in than each grape began to redden, and assumed the hue of ripeness;
tgt_text.7522: and among them was represented Bac­ chus himself as dresser of the vineyard.
tgt_text.7523: As the feast went on, and the good wine did its office, I began to cast bold lawless glances at Leucippe;
tgt_text.7524: for Love and Bacchus are two very potent deities, they take possession of the soul ‡ and so inflame it that it forgets every restraint of modesty;
tgt_text.7525: the one kindles in it a flame, and the other supplies fuel for the fire, for wine may truly be called the meat and drink of love.
tgt_text.7526: The maiden also became gradually emboldened so as to gaze at me more fixedly.
tgt_text.7527: In this manner, ten days passed on without anything beyond glances being inter­ changed between us.
tgt_text.7528: At length I imparted the whole affair to Satyrus, request­ ing his assistance;
tgt_text.7529: he replied, " I knew it all before you told me, but was unwilling that you should be aware of the fact, supposing it your wish to remain unobserved;
tgt_text.7530: for very often he who loves by stealth hates the party who has dis­ covered his passion, and considers himself to have received an insult from him.
tgt_text.7531: However," continued he, " fortune has provided for our contingences,* for Clio, Leucippe's chamber­ maid, has an understanding with me, and admits me as her lover.
tgt_text.7532: I will gradually buy her over to give us her assist­ ance in this affair;
tgt_text.7533: but you, on your part, must not be con­ tent with making trial of the maiden merely by glances;
tgt_text.7534: you must speak to her and say something to the point, then take a farther step by touching her hand, squeezing her fingers, and fetching a deep sigh;
tgt_text.7535: if she permits this willingly, then salute her as the mistress of your affections, and imprint a kiss upon her neck." " By Pallas, you counsel wisely," was my reply, " but I fear me, I shall prove but a craven wrestler in the school of love.""
tgt_text.7536: The god of love," said he, " has no notion of craven- heartedness ;
tgt_text.7537: do you not see in what warlike guise be is equipped ?
tgt_text.7538: He bears a bow, a quiver, arrows, and a lighted torch, emblems all of them, of manhood and of daring.
tgt_text.7539: Filled, then, as land are with the influence of such a god, are you a coward and do you tremble ?
tgt_text.7540: Beware of shewing yourself merely a counterfeit in love.
tgt_text.7541: I will make an open­ ing by calling away Clio, as soon as an opportunity occurs for your having a private conversation with Leucippe."
tgt_text.7542: With these words he left the room;
tgt_text.7543: excited by what he had said, I was no sooner alone, then I used every endea­ vour to collect my courage for the approaching interview.
tgt_text.7544: " Coward," said I, " how long wilt thou continue silent P Thou, the soldier of such a warlike ‛ god, and yet a craven.'
tgt_text.7545: Dost thou intend to wait until the maiden comes to thee of her own accord ? "
tgt_text.7546: Afterwards I proceeded, " and yet fool that thou art, why not come to thy senses ?
tgt_text.7547: Why not bestow thy love upon a lawful object ?
tgt_text.7548: Thou hast another maiden in this house;
tgt_text.7550: Be con­ tent with loving her, and gazing upon her;
tgt_text.7551: her it is per­ mitted thee to take to wife."
tgt_text.7553: when from the bottom of my heart Love spoke in reply and said;
tgt_text.7555: Rash man, darest thou to set thyself in array and to war with me—me, who have wings to fly, arrows to wound, and a torch to burn ?
tgt_text.7557: If thou wardest off my shafts, how wilt thou avert my fire P and even supposing thy chastity should quench the flame, still I can overtake thee with my wings.”
tgt_text.7558: *While engaged in this soliloquy, the maiden unexpectedly made her appearance ;
tgt_text.7559: I turned pale, and the next moment became crimson;
tgt_text.7560: she was quite alone, not even Clio accom­ panied her;
tgt_text.7561: in a very confused manner, and not knowing what else to say, I addressed her with the words, " Good morrow, fair mistress;
tgt_text.7562: ” sweetly smiling, she shewed by her countenance that she comprehended the drift of my salu­ tation, and said, “ Do you call me your mistress ?" "
tgt_text.7563: Indeed I do, for one of the gods has told me to be your slave, as Her­ cules was sold to Omphale."
tgt_text.7564: “ Sold, if I remember, by Mercury,” rejoined she, " and Jove employed him in the business;
tgt_text.7565: " this she said with an arch smile ? "
tgt_text.7566: What non­ sense," rejoined I, " to trifle so, and talk of Mercury when all the while you understood my meaning." t
tgt_text.7567: While one pleasantry led on to another and so prolonged our conver­ sation, fortune came to my assistance.
tgt_text.7568: About noon on the preceding day, Leucippe had been playing on the harp and Clio was sitting beside her.
tgt_text.7569: I was walking up and down, when suddenly a bee flying in, stung Clio's hand;
tgt_text.7570: she immediately shrieked out, upon which the maiden, hastily rising from her seat and laying aside the harp, examined the wound, bidding her to be under no anxiety, for that she could relieve the pain by simply uttering two magic words, having been instructed by an Egyptian how to cure the stings inflicted by bees and wasps;
tgt_text.7571: she then proceeded to utter the words of mean- tation, and Clio, in a few moments declared the pain to be relieved.
tgt_text.7572: This, as I intimated, took place on the day before.
tgt_text.7573: On the present occasion it chanced, that a bee or wasp flew buzzing round my face, when all at once the idea seized me of feigning myself to have been stung ;
tgt_text.7575: I did so, putting my hand to my face, and pretending to be in pain.
tgt_text.7576: The maiden came up to me, removed my hand and enquired where I had been stung;
tgt_text.7577: upon my lips, dearest, was my reply, why do you not charm away the pain ?
tgt_text.7578: Ap­ proaching my face, she placed her mouth almost close to mine, in order to work the charm, at the same time mur­ muring certain words, and ever and anon touching my lips.
tgt_text.7579: All this time I kept stealing silent kisses, so that from the maiden alternately opening and closing her lips while uttering the charm, the incantation became changed into one continuous kiss.
tgt_text.7580: At last putting my arms around her, I saluted her lips more ardently ;
tgt_text.7581: upon which drawing back she exclaimed, “ What are you about ?
tgt_text.7583: I am only kissing the charm which has removed my pain."
tgt_text.7584: She took my meaning and smiled, which gave me a fresh supply of courage.
tgt_text.7586: Ah! dear Leucippe,' I exclaimed, “I now feel another and severer sting,† one which has penetrated to my very heart, and calls for your ‛ mighty magic ;
tgt_text.7587: ’ surely you must carry about a bee upon your lips they are full of honey, your kisses wound;
tgt_text.7588: repeat the charm, I pray, but do not hurry over the operation, for fear of exasperating the wound at the same time I embraced her more closely and kissed her with still greater freedom;
tgt_text.7589: nor, though making a show of resistance, did she seem displeased. *
tgt_text.7590: At this juncture Clio was seen approaching from a distance, upon which we separated, I much annoyed and sorely against my will ;
tgt_text.7591: what were her feelings I cannot exactly say.
tgt_text.7592: After what had passed, however, I felt easier in mind and began to indulge in brighter hopes.
tgt_text.7593: I still felt the kiss upon my lips as though it bad really been something of a corporeal nature;
tgt_text.7594: I zealously guarded it as a treasure of sweets, for a kiss is to the lover his chief delight;
tgt_text.7595: it takes its birth from the fairest portion of the human body-from the mouth, which is the instrument of the voice, and the voice is the adumbration of the soul;
tgt_text.7596: when lips mingle they dart pleasure through the veins, and make even the lovers’ souls join in the embrace.
tgt_text.7597: Never before did I feel delight comparable to this;
tgt_text.7598: and then for the first time I learnt that no pleasurable sensation can vie with a lover's kiss.
tgt_text.7599: †At supper time we met as on former occasions, when Satyrus, who acted as cupbearer, hit upon the following amorous device.
tgt_text.7600: After our cups were filled, he effected an exchange, presenting mine to the maiden, handing hers to me.
tgt_text.7601: Having noticed what part of the brim had been touched by her in drinking, I applied my lips to the same place thus intimating that I was sending her a kiss.
tgt_text.7602: She remarked what I had done, and readily understood that I had been kissing the shadow of her lips.
tgt_text.7603: Satyrus ngain stealthily made a like exchange of cups, when 1 could observe her imitating me, and drinking as I bad done, which, as you may imagine, vastly increased my happiness.
tgt_text.7604: This was repeated a third and fourth time;
tgt_text.7605: in short, we passed the rest of the time in drinking kisses to one another.
tgt_text.7606: When supper was ended, Satyrus approaching me said, " Now is the time to show your mettle;
tgt_text.7607: the maiden's mother, as you are aware, is unwell, and has retired to rest alone.
tgt_text.7608: She herself before going to bed will take a few turns as usual in the garden, attended by no one but Clio, whom I will undertake to get out of the way.
tgt_text.7609: We then separated, and remained on the watch, he for Clio, I for Leucippe.
tgt_text.7610: Everything turned out as we had wished ;
tgt_text.7611: Clio was got rid of, and Leucippe remained walking by herself.
tgt_text.7612: I waited till the daylight had faded away,* and then approached her, emboldened by my former success, like a soldier already victorious, who therefore scorns the perils of war.
tgt_text.7613: The arms in which I trusted were wine, love, hope, and solitude;
tgt_text.7614: so, without saying a word, and as if every­ thing had been preconcerted, I took her in my arms, and covered her with kisses.
tgt_text.7615: When about to proceed to other familiarities, a noise was heard behind us, at which we started asunder in alarm.
tgt_text.7616: She betook herself to her chamber, and I remained there in great dudgeon at having lost so capital an opportunity, and execrating the noise which had been the cause.
tgt_text.7617: Meanwhile Satyrus came up with a laughing countenance.
tgt_text.7618: He had witnessed everything, having concealed himselt under a tree to guard against our surprise ;
tgt_text.7619: and it was be, who seeing some one approach, had made the noise.
tgt_text.7620: In the course of a few days, my father made preparations for concluding my marriage sooner than had been originally intended.
tgt_text.7621: He had been much alarmed by various dreams;
tgt_text.7622: be thought he was celebrating the nuptial rites, and after the torches had been kindled the light was suddenly extin­ guished.
tgt_text.7623: This made him more anxious to conclude the matter, and we were now within a day of the one formally appointed for the ceremony.
tgt_text.7624: The wedding clothes and jewels were already purchased;
tgt_text.7625: there was a necklace com­ posed of various gems, and a splendid purple robe edged with a gold border.
tgt_text.7626: The gems vied with each other in beauty;
tgt_text.7627: among them was a hyacinth,* which resembled a rose, only that it was a stone, and an amethyst almost as lustrous as gold itself.
tgt_text.7628: In the middle of this necklace were three precious stones, arranged together and curiously blended in their hues;
tgt_text.7629: the lowest one was black, the middle white, but with a darkish tinge, the upper one shading off into a ruddy colour.
tgt_text.7630: They were set in a rim of gold, and might be said to bear resemblance to an eye†.
tgt_text.7631: The purple of the dress was of no ordinary dye, but of the kind which the Tyrians fable to have been discovered by the shepherd's dog, and with which they are wont to represent the robe of Venus‡ to be tinged.
tgt_text.7632: There was a time when this purple dye was as yet unknown, but remained concealed in the hollow of a little shell fish.
tgt_text.7633: A shepherd meeting with one of these hoped to obtain the fish which was inside;
tgt_text.7634: foiled by the hardness of the shell, after bestowing a hearty curse upon his booty, he threw it into the sea as so much worthless rubbish.
tgt_text.7635: His dog lighted upon this windfall,§ and broke open the shell with his teeth, in doing which his mouth and lips became stained with the brilliant dye, or as we may call it, blood.
tgt_text.7636: The shepherd upon seeing this supposed it the effect of a wound;
tgt_text.7637: so taking the dog down to the sea he washed his mouth, upon which the imaginary blood assumed a still more brilliant hue, and upon proceed­ ing to touch it, his hand became of a purple colour.
tgt_text.7638: The shepherd now guessed what was the nature of the shell fish, and that it was impregnated with a dye of surpassing beauty;
tgt_text.7639: so taking some wool he placed it in the aperture, determined to dive into the mysteries of the shell;
tgt_text.7640: and it became of a colour similar to that upon the dog's mouth.
tgt_text.7641: By this means he obtained a knowledge of what we call purple;
tgt_text.7642: and after breaking open its fortified receptacle with the help of a stone, he arrived at the treasure-house of dye.
tgt_text.7643: To return, however, to my story.
tgt_text.7644: My father was performing the preliminary rites,* the marriage being fixed, as I have said, for the following day.
tgt_text.7645: I was in despair, and was devising some pretext for deferring it.
tgt_text.7646: While in this state of per­ plexity, a great tumult was heard to proceed from the men's quarter of the house.
tgt_text.7647: It appeared that as my father was offering up a sacrifice;
tgt_text.7648: an eaglet swooping from on high seized the victim, and in spite of every endeavour to scare him away, bore off his prey.
tgt_text.7649: As this was declared to fore­ bode no good, the marriage was postponed for another day.
tgt_text.7650: My father proceeded to consult the seers and soothsayers upon the meaning of the portent;
tgt_text.7651: they were of opinion that he should offer a sacrifice to hospitable Jove at midnight upon the sea-shore, since the bird had flown in that direction.
tgt_text.7652: Sure enough he had winged his flight thither, and appeared no more.
tgt_text.7653: For my part, I extolled the eagle to the skies, and declared that he was justly styled the king‡ of birds.
tgt_text.7654: No long time elapsed before the meaning of the prodigy became revealed.
tgt_text.7655: There was a certain young man, a native of Byzantium, by name Callisthenes;
tgt_text.7656: he was an orphan and possessed of wealth, profligate in his life and extravagant in nis expenditure, Having heard that Sostra­ tus had a handsome daughter, he was anxious to obtain her hand and became enamoured upon hearsay, for he had never seen her.§
tgt_text.7657: The force of passion upon the licentious is often so strong that their ears lead them into love, and report has the same effect upon their minds which sight has upon others.
tgt_text.7658: Before the breaking out of the war against the Byzantians, the young man introduced himself to Sostratus, and asked the hand of his daughter in marriage.
tgt_text.7659: Sostratus, however, strongly objecting to his irregular way of life, rejected his application.
tgt_text.7660: Callisthenes was very indignant at this repulse ;
tgt_text.7662: —besides, he was in love, and fancy pictured to his mind those charms which he had never seen.
tgt_text.7663: Dissembling his displeasure, he meditated how he might -revenge himself on Sostratus, and at the same time gratify his own desires;
tgt_text.7664: nor was he without hope of success, there being a law of the Byzautians which enacted, that if any one should carry off a maiden he should be exempt from punishment upon making her his wife of this law he determined to avail himself, and waited only till a seasonable opportunity should offer.
tgt_text.7665: Although the war had now broken out, and the maiden had come to us for security, he did not abandon his design, in the execution of which the following circumstance assisted, as the Byzan­ tians had received an oracle to this effect:
tgt_text.7666: — " With plant-born name there lives an island race, Whose land an isthmus to the shore doth brace;
tgt_text.7667: Vulcan consorts there with the blue-eyed maid, And there to Hercules be offerings paid."
tgt_text.7668: +While all were in doubt what place was intended by these enigmatic words, Sostratus (who was one of the commanders) thus delivered his opinion :
tgt_text.7670: We must send to Tyre, ana offer up a sacrifice to Hercules ;
tgt_text.7671: ‡ the expressions of the oracle clearly point to that city.
tgt_text.7672: The plant-derived name,' shews that the island of the Phœnicians is intended, the phœnix (or palm), being a plant;
tgt_text.7673: both sea and land lay claim to it:
tgt_text.7674: the latter joins it to the continent, the former washes it on either side ;
tgt_text.7675: thus it is seated in the one element, but without abandoning the other, to which it is united by its narrow isthmus or neck of land;
tgt_text.7676: moreover, it is not founded in the sea, but both under it and under the isthmus, the waters have free course;
tgt_text.7677: thus there is seen the singular spectacle of a city in the sea, and of an island upon shore.
tgt_text.7678: The mention made of ‘ Vulcan consorting with the blue.
tgt_text.7679: eyed maid,' alludes to the olive and the fire, which are found there in close proximity:
tgt_text.7680: for, in a sacred precinct surrounded by a wall, olive trees are seen to flourisn, while fire issuing from their roots burns among the branches, and with its ashes benefits the tree;
tgt_text.7681: hence there exists a mutual friendship, and Minerva shuns not Vulcan."
tgt_text.7682: Upon this Chærophon, who shared the command with Sostratus in the war, his senior in ago and a native of Tyre, extolled him highly for his excellent interpretation of the oracle.
tgt_text.7684: It is not only fire, however," said he, " which claims our wonder;
tgt_text.7685: the water also deserves its share.
tgt_text.7686: I myself have seen the following marvels :
tgt_text.7687: -there is a fountain in Sicily whose waters are mingled with fire;
tgt_text.7688: the flame is seen to leap up from underneath, yet if you touch the water it will be found as cold as snow, so that neither is the fire extinguished by the water, nor the water ignited by the flame, but a mutual truce subsists between the elements*.
tgt_text.7689: There is also a river in Spain, not differing from others in appearance, but if you wish to hear it become vocal, you have but to wait and listen;
tgt_text.7690: for when a gentle breeze sweeps over its surface there is heard a sound as if from strings, the wind being the plectrum, the river itself the lyre.†
tgt_text.7691: I may likewise men­ ion a lake in Lybia, resembling in its nature the Indian soil.‡
tgt_text.7692: The Lybian maidens are well acquainted with its secrets and with the riches which, stored below its waters, are mingled with the mud, for it is, in fact, a fount of gold.
tgt_text.7693: Plunging a long pole smeared with pitch into the lake, they lay open its recesses ;
tgt_text.7694: this pole is to the gold what the hook is to the fish, serving as a bait.
tgt_text.7695: The grains of gold alone attach themselves to the pitch, and are drawn on shore.
tgt_text.7696: Such is the gold-fishing in the Lybian waters.
tgt_text.7697: After relating these marvels, Chærephon, with the consent of the state, proceeded to dispatch the victims and other offerings to Tyre.
tgt_text.7698: Callistbenes contrived to be among the number of the sacred functionaries.* and soon arriving at that city, he found out my father's residence, and matured his schemes against the females, who, as will presently be shown, went out to view the sacrificial show, which was in the highest degree sumptuous ;
tgt_text.7699: there was a vast quantity of different kinds of incense used, such as cassia, frankin­ cense, and crocus ;
tgt_text.7700: there was also a great display of flowers, the narcissus, the rose, and the myrtle;
tgt_text.7701: the fragrance of the flowers vied with the perfumes of the incense;
tgt_text.7702: the breeze wafted them aloft, mingled their odours in the air, producing n gale of sweets.
tgt_text.7703: The victims were many in number and of various kinds;
tgt_text.7704: the most remarkable among them, how­ ever, were the oxen from the Nile, animals which excel not only in stature but in colours.
tgt_text.7705: They arc altogether of very large size, with brawny necks, broad backs, and ample bellies ;
tgt_text.7706: t their horns are not depressed, like those of the Sicilian ox, nor ill-shaped like the Cyprian, but project upward from the forehead of this animal with a gentle curve;
tgt_text.7707: the interval between them at their tips and at the roots being equal, so that they bear a resemblance to the moon when at the full;
tgt_text.7708: their colour is that which Homer so much praises in the Thracian horses.‡
tgt_text.7709: The bull stalks along with lofty crest, as if to show that he is the monarch of the herd.
tgt_text.7710: If there is any truth in the legend of Europa, it was into an Egyptian bull that Jove metamorphosed himself.
tgt_text.7711: At the time of which I am speaking my mother-in-law was unwell;
tgt_text.7712: Leucippe also feigned indisposition, accord­ ing to a preconcerted arrangement, that we might have an opportunity of meeting during the absence of the rest
tgt_text.7713: My sister, therefore, and Leucippe's mother were the only ones who went out to see the show.
tgt_text.7714: Callisthenes, who knew by sight the wife of Sostratus, seeing my Mister in her company mistook her for Leucippe, of whom he had no personal knowledge.
tgt_text.7715: Smitten by her appearance, and with­ out making any inquiries, he points her out to a trusty attendant of his, commanding him to engage some pirates to effect her seizure, and arranging the manner of proceed­ ing, for a high festival* was at hand when, as he under­ stood, all the maidens would go down to the shore for the purpose of performing their ablutions.
tgt_text.7716: After giving these directions, and having discharged the duties of his function†, he withdrew.
tgt_text.7717: He had previously, I may remark, provided a vessel of his own, in case an opportunity should offer for carrying his schemes into effect.
tgt_text.7718: Meanwhile the rest of the sacred functionaries had em­ barked and sailed away;
tgt_text.7719: he, however, went on board his vessel, and continued to lie a little off shore, both in order that lie might appear to be taking his departure like the others, and also lest, being so near Tyre, any danger should happen to himself in consequence of carrying off the maiden.
tgt_text.7720: Upon arriving at Sarepta, a Tyrian village on the sea-coast, be purchased another craft, which he intrusted to his fol­ lower Zeno, who was to execute his plan.
tgt_text.7721: This man was able-bodied, and accustomed to a buccaneering life;
tgt_text.7722: he soon, therefore, succeeded in gathering together some pirates from the above-named village, and then sailed for Tyre.
tgt_text.7723: Near this city there is an islet with a harbour, (the Tyrians call it the tomb of Rhodope);
tgt_text.7724: here the craft was stationed watching for the prey.
tgt_text.7725: Before the arrival of the high festival, however, which Callisthenes awaited, the omen of the eagle and the interpretation of the soothsayers were fulfilled.
tgt_text.7726: On the day preceding, we made preparations for the sacrifice to Jove, and late in the evening went down to the shore;
tgt_text.7727: none of our motions escaped Zeno, who cau­ tiously followed us.
tgt_text.7728: When in the act of performing our ablutions, he made the preconcerted signal, upon which the boat made rapidly for the land, manned by ten young fel­ lows;
tgt_text.7729: eight others were secretly in readiness on shore, dressed in women'is clothes and with shaven chins;
tgt_text.7730: each had a sword concealed under his dress, and the better to avoid any suspicion, they had brought some victims with them as for sacrifice, so that we took them to be women.
tgt_text.7731: No sooner had we reached the pile than, raising a sudden shout, they rushed upon us, and put out our torches;
tgt_text.7732: we fled disorderly and in alarm, upon which they drew their swords, and seizing my sister, put her into the boat, and then embarking rowed off with the speed of an eagle.
tgt_text.7733: Some who had fled at the first onset saw nothing of what after­ wards occurred;
tgt_text.7734: others who had witnessed everything cried out, " The pirates have carried off Calligone.
tgt_text.7735: "Meanwhile the boat was far out at sea, and upon nearing Sarepta made a signal which when Callisthenes recognised, he put out to meet it, and taking the maiden on board his own vessel, at once sailed away.
tgt_text.7736: I breathed again upon ending my marriage thus unexpectedly broken off, never­ theless I was sorry for the calamity which had befallen my sister.
tgt_text.7737: A few days after this occurrence, I said to Leu­ cippe, "How long, my dearest, are we to confine ourselves to kisses ?
tgt_text.7738: they are pleasant enough as preludes, let us now add to them something more substantial:
