tgt_text.7977: With women their words and postures, everything, in short, is studied and artificial:
tgt_text.7978: and their beauty, if they possess any, is the labo­ rious work of cosmetic appliances, of perfumes and of dyes divest them of these meretricious attractions, and they will appear like the daw stripped of its feathers, which we read of in the fable.
tgt_text.7979: The beauty of youths, on the other hand, requires no unguents or artificial essences to recommend it;
tgt_text.7980: nature has made it complete and sufficient in itself."
tgt_text.7981: tON the third day of our voyage a sudden change took place in the weather;
tgt_text.7982: the sky, which had been clear, grew so black as quite to obscure the light of day, and a violent gale ploughing up the sea blew directly in our teeth.
tgt_text.7983: Upon this, the master ordered the yard to be brought round;
tgt_text.7984: ‡ the sailors speedily obeyed, furling one-half of the sail by dint of great exertions, but were compelled by the violence of the wind to leave the other unfurled.
tgt_text.7985: In consequence of this manœuvre one side of the vessel began to heel, while the contrary side became proportionally elevated, so that we every moment expected to be capsized, as the gale continued to blow with undiminished fury.
tgt_text.7986: To prevent this, and to restore, if possible, the vessel’s equilibrium, we all scrambled to the side highest out of water, but it was of no avail.
tgt_text.7987: We ourselves, indeed, were raised, but the position of the ship was in no way altered;
tgt_text.7988: after long and vain endeavours to right her, the wind suddenly shifted, almost submerging the side which had been elevated, and raising high out of the water that previously depressed.
tgt_text.7989: An universal shriek arose from those on board, and nothing remained but to hurry back to our former station.
tgt_text.7990: We repeated this several times, our movements keeping pace with the shifting of the vessel;
tgt_text.7991: indeed, we had scarcely succeeded in hurrying to one side, before we were obliged to hurry back in the con­ trary direction.
tgt_text.7992: Like those who run backwards and forwards in the course,.
tgt_text.7993: we continued these alternate movements during a great part of the day, momentarily expecting death, who, as it seemed, was not far off;
tgt_text.7994: for about noon the sun entirely disappeared, and we saw each other as if by moon­ light ;
tgt_text.7995: lightnings flashed from the clouds, the thunder rolled, filling the sky with its echoes, which were repeated from below by the strife of waters, while in the intermediate space was heard the shouts of the discordant winds,!
tgt_text.7996: so that the air seemed one mighty trumpet;
tgt_text.7997: the ropes break­ ing loose rattled against the sail and against each other till at last they were rent in pieces.
tgt_text.7998: We now began to be in no small fear that the vessel, from the shattered condition of her sides, would open and go to pieces;
tgt_text.8000: too were flooded, being continually washed over by the waves.
tgt_text.8001: We however crawled under them for protection, and abandon­ log all hope resigned ourselves to Fortune.
tgt_text.8002: Tremendous billows following in quick succession tumbled one over the other, some in front, some at the sides of the ship, which as they approached was lifted high up as if upon a mountain, and when they retired was plunged down as into an abyss.t
tgt_text.8003: The most formidable were those which broke against the sides and made their way over the bulwarks, flooding all the vessel;
tgt_text.8004: even while approaching from a distance these were formidable enough, almost touching, as they did, the clouds;
tgt_text.8005: but when they neared and broke, you would have supposed that the ship must inevitably be swallowed up.
tgt_text.8006: We could scarcely keep our feet, so violent was the rolling of the vessel, and a confused din of sounds was heard ;
tgt_text.8007: -the sea roared, the wind blustered, the women shrieked, the men shouted, the sailors called to one another:
tgt_text.8009: ‡At length the master ordered the cargo to be thrown overboard;
tgt_text.8010: no distinction was made between gold and silver, and the commonest articles,-all were pitched over the sides;
tgt_text.8011: many of the merchants with their own hands tumbling into the sea the goods on which all their hopes were centred.
tgt_text.8012: By these means the ship was lightened, but the storm did not in any degree abate.
tgt_text.8013: At length the master, wearied out and in despair, let go the tiller, abandoned the ship to the waves, and standing at the gangway ordered the boats to be got ready and the sailors to embark.
tgt_text.8014: Upon this a fearful scene of strife arose;
tgt_text.8015: the sailors in the boat were beginning to cut the rope which attached it to the ship.
tgt_text.8016: Seeing this, the passengers endeavoured to leap in, which the crew would not allow, threatening with their swords and axes any who should venture on the attempt.
tgt_text.8017: The others upon this arm­ ing themselves as best they could with shattered oars and broken benches, showed a determination to retaliate, for in a storm might, not right, must settle matters.
tgt_text.8018: A novel kind of sea-fight now commenced;
tgt_text.8019: they in the boat, fearful of being swamped by the numbers who were descending from the vessel, laid about them in good earnest with their swords and axes;
tgt_text.8020: which the passengers as they leaped in were not backward in returning with their poles and oars, and some scarcely touched the boat before they fell into the water;
tgt_text.8021: others, who had succeeded in getting in, were strug­ gling with the sailors to maintain their ground.
tgt_text.8022: The laws of friendship or neighbourly regard were no longer heeded;
tgt_text.8023: each looked to his own preservation, careless of the safety of any other;
tgt_text.8024: for the effect of pressing danger is, that it dissolves even the tenderest ties.
tgt_text.8025: One of the passengers, a robust young fellow, succeeded at last in getting hold of the rope and dragging the boat towards the vessel;
tgt_text.8026: every one on board holding himself ready to leap in.
tgt_text.8027: A few succeeded in the endeavour, though not without receiving injuries;
tgt_text.8028: many in their attempt were plunged into the sea.
tgt_text.8029: The crew without further delay, cutting the rope with their axes, put off, and committed themselves to the mercy of the winds;
tgt_text.8030: those on board in the meantime having used every exertion to sink the boat.
tgt_text.8031: The vessel, after continuing for some time to pitch and roll upon the waves, was carried upon a sunken rock, when she struck and soon went to pieces, the mast falling over on one side and hastening her destruction.
tgt_text.8032: They who were at once swallowed up in the briny waves experienced a happier lot than their companions, in not having to remain with death before their eyes ;
tgt_text.8033: for at sea the anticipation of drowning kills even before death actually arrives;
tgt_text.8034: the eye, bewildered by the expanse of waters, can set no limits to its fears:
tgt_text.8035: this it is which gives death so much more bitterness.
tgt_text.8036: and makes it re. garded with dread proportioned to the vasty nature of the sea itself.
tgt_text.8037: *Upon the present occasion some were dashed against rocks and perished, others were pierced by pieces of broken spars, and some were seen swimming in a half-exhausted state.
tgt_text.8038: When the vessel was wrecked, some good genius preserved a portion of the prow, upon which I and Leucippe being seated, were carried along by the current;
tgt_text.8039: Menelaus, Satyrus, and some other passengers, had thrown themselves across the mast;
tgt_text.8040: Clinias at no great distance was swimming supported by the yard, and we could hear him calling out, “Hold on, Clitopho !”
tgt_text.8041: In a moment a wavo washed over him;
tgt_text.8042: at which sad spectacle we shrieked aloud.
tgt_text.8043: Rolling onward in our direction, it happily passed us, and we again caught sight of the yard, and Clinias riding upon its crest. “ 0, mighty Neptune," exclaimed I, with a deep groan, “ take pity on us, and spare the remnants of this shipwreck;
tgt_text.8044: our terror has caused us already to die many deaths;
tgt_text.8045: if it be thy will to destroy us, do not divide us in our deaths;
tgt_text.8047: or if we are fated to become food for the monsters of the deep let one devour us;
tgt_text.8048: —let us have one common death, one common tomb."
tgt_text.8049: I had not long uttered this prayer before the violence of the wind abated and the roughness of the waves subsided, and the surface of the sea was seen covered with floating bodies.
tgt_text.8050: Menelaus and his companions were thrown by the waves upon a part of the coast of Egypt which was at that time the general haunt of buccaneers.
tgt_text.8051: Late in the evening, Leucippe and I contrived to reach Pelusium, and upon getting to land thanked the gods for our escape;
tgt_text.8052: nor did we omit bewailing Clinias and Satyrus, believing them to have been drowned.
tgt_text.8053: In the temple of Casian* Jupiter, at Pelusium, there is the statue of a youth very like Apollo ;
tgt_text.8054: his hand is stretched out and holds a pomegranate, which has a mystic meaning.†
tgt_text.8055: After praying to this deity, and asking tidings of Clinias and Satyrus (for the god is believed to be prophetic) we walked about the temple;
tgt_text.8056: in the treasury‡ at the rear ot this edifice we saw two pictures by the artist Evanthes.
tgt_text.8057: The subject of one was Andromeda, of the other, Prome­ theus.
tgt_text.8058: Both were represented as bound, for which reason probably the painter had associated them together.
tgt_text.8059: They furnished other points of resemblance also;
tgt_text.8060: both had a rock for their prison house, and savage beasts for their executioners, the one being a bird of prey, the other a sea monster.
tgt_text.8061: The champions also who came to their rescue were both Grecians, Hercules and Perseus.
tgt_text.8062: The former is represented standing on the ground and aiming his arrow at the bird of Jove;
tgt_text.8063: the latter poised in air directs his attack against the fish.
tgt_text.8064: The rock is hollowed out, so as to suit the size of the maiden’s body, and the rugged surface given it by the painter, plainly showed that it is intended to represent a production of nature, not the work of art;
tgt_text.8065: the maiden is fixed in the hollow of this rock, her lovely form giving her the appearance of a wondrously-carved statue,§ but the chains and the sea-monster betokening a hastily-planned tomb.||
tgt_text.8066: Beauty and fear are mingled in her countenance, yet the pallor of her cheeks is not wholly untinged with colour, while the brightness of her eyes is tempered by a languor such as is seen in violets when they begin to fade;
tgt_text.8067: thus had the painter imparted to her the expression of comely fear.¶
tgt_text.8068: Her arms, extended on either side, are chained against the rock, the wrists and fingers hanging down like the clusters from the vine;
tgt_text.8069: her arms are of spotless white, but approaching to a livid hue, and her fingers appear bloodless.
tgt_text.8070: Bound in this fashion she is awaiting death.
tgt_text.8071: Her attire is bridal, of white, and reaching to the feet, of a texture so fine as to resemble a spider’s web, the production not of the wool of sheep, but of the down of winged insects whose webs Indian women gather from the trees and weaver
tgt_text.8072: The monster is emerging from the sea opposite the maiden;
tgt_text.8073: his head alone appears above the waves, but the outline of his body is distinguishable beneath the water:
tgt_text.8074: the junctures of his scales, the curvature of his back, the ridge of his spines, the twisting of his tail;
tgt_text.8075: his immense jaws are expanded as far as his shoulders, and to the very entrance of his maw.
tgt_text.8076: In the intermediate space is seen Perseus descending from the sky, his body naked, with the exception of a mantle about his shoulders, winged sandals upon his feet, and a cap resembling Pluto's helmet† upon his head;
tgt_text.8077: in his left hand he grasps the Gorgon's head, holding it forth in the manner of a shield ;
tgt_text.8078: the face is fearful to behold, and even on the painter's canvas seems to glare with its eyes, to bristle up its locks, to shake its ser­ pentis.
tgt_text.8079: Ills right hand is armed with a weapon between a straight sword and a scimitar;
tgt_text.8080: from the hilt to the middle it is a sword, it then partakes of both, remaining sharp so as to inflict a wound, and becoming curved in order to follow up and improve the stroke.
tgt_text.8082: "Next to it, as I before remarked, was a painting of Pro­ metheus bound to the rock.
tgt_text.8083: Hercules stands near him, armed with his bow and arrows.
tgt_text.8084: The vulture is feasting upon his side, in which it has inflicted a lacerating wound, and with its beak inserted in the opening, seems to be digging after the liver, of which the painter allows a portion to be visible.-
tgt_text.8085: The talons of the bird are firmly planted upon the thigh of Prometheus, who shrinks with agony, contracts his side, and draws back his leg to his own hurt, for the movement brings the eagle nearer to his liver.
tgt_text.8086: The other leg is stretched out straight before him, and the tension of the muscles is visible to the extreme point of the toes ;
tgt_text.8087: f his whole appearance is that of acute suffering, his eyebrows are contracted, his lips drawn in, and his teeth appear;
tgt_text.8088: you could almost compassionate the painting, as though itself felt pain.
tgt_text.8089: In his misery, Hercules is come to his aid, and is preparing to transfix his tormentor ;
tgt_text.8090: already the arrow is on the bow, which he extends with his left hand, while with his right hand he draws the string to his breast;
tgt_text.8091: in doing which the elbow is seen shortened from behind.
tgt_text.8092: The stretching of the bow, the drawing back the string, the hand touching the breast, all seemed the work of a single moment.‡
tgt_text.8093: Prometheus appears divided between hope and fear;
tgt_text.8094: be looks partly at his wounded side, partly at Her­ cules ;
tgt_text.8095: fain would he fix his eyes upon him alone ;
tgt_text.8096: but his agony turns them back, in part, upon himself.
tgt_text.8097: After remaining two days at Pelusium to recruit our­ selves after our fatigues, having fortunately some money left we engaged an Egyptian vessel, and proceeded by way of the Nile to Alexandria, with the intention of making some stay there, thinking likewise that we might find in that city some of our shipwrecked friends.
tgt_text.8098: Upon nearing a certain town, not far from the river, we suddenly heard a loud shout;
tgt_text.8099: upon which the master exclaiming, " The buc­ caneers are upon us!” endeavoured to put about his vessel, and to sail back, when in a moment the bark was thronged with men of formidable and savage mien.
tgt_text.8100: They were all tall and stout;
tgt_text.8101: their complexion was black,-not the jet black of the Indians, but that of a mongrel Ethiopian;
tgt_text.8102: they had shaven heads and very small feet, and spoke a barbarous dialect..
tgt_text.8103: As this was the narrowest part of the river, escape was impossible;
tgt_text.8104: so the master exclaiming, “We are all lost !” brought the vessel to.
tgt_text.8105: Four of the buccaneers came on board and carried off everything which they could lay hands on, not forgetting our stock of money ;
tgt_text.8106: we were then taken on shore, bound and shut up in a hut, when the greater part of them rode away, leaving guards, who were to conduct us next day to the king, as their chief is styled, who, as we learnt from our fellow captives, was about two days' journey distant.
tgt_text.8107: When night came on, and we were lying there bound and our guards were asleep, I found leisure to bewail Leucippe, reflecting how many calamities I had brought upon her.
tgt_text.8108: Deeply groaning in soul, and carefully suppress­ ing any outward sound of grief, "Oh, ye gods and genii I said within myself, " if ye really exist and hear me, what heinous crimes have we committed, that in a few short days we should bo plunged into such a depth of misery P
tgt_text.8109: And now, to crown all, ye have delivered us into the hands of Egyptian buccaneers, cutting us off from any chance of pity.
tgt_text.8110: Our voice and our entreaties might mollify the heart of a Grecian pirate ;
tgt_text.8111: for words oftentimes beget com­ passion, and the tongue ministering to the necessities of the soul, subdues the angry feeling of the hearer;
tgt_text.8112: but in our present case, what language can we employ, what oaths -if submission can we take ?
tgt_text.8113: Had I tones more persuasive than the Syrens', these barbarian homicides would neither understand nor listen to me;
tgt_text.8114: I must then be content to supplicate with signs and gestures, and pantomimic t show;
tgt_text.8115: it is not so much for my own misfortunes, severe as they are, which I lament;
tgt_text.8116: but how shall I sufficiently bewail, how sufficiently weep for thine, Leucippe, thou who hast shown thyself so faithful in all the straits of love, so tender towards thy unhappy lover!
tgt_text.8117: Behold, the splendid pre­ paration for thy marriage ;
tgt_text.8118: a prison for thy bridal chamber, earth for thy couch, the noose and the rope for thy neck­ laces and bracelets, a pirate for thy bridesman,* a dirge for thy nuptial hymn.
tgt_text.8120: I have thanked thee without reason;
tgt_text.8121: rather should I upbraid thee for thy mercy;
tgt_text.8122: greater in reality has been thy kindness to those whom thou hast drowned;
tgt_text.8123: our preservation deserves rather to be called destruc­ tion, for thou hast grudged us death except by the bands of buccaneers."
tgt_text.8124: In this manner did I inwardly lament, but no tears came to my relief;
tgt_text.8125: this is indeed peculiar to the eyes in all great misfortunes;
tgt_text.8126: in the season of any ordinary grief, they flow readily enough,† and then they not only serve as intercessors between the sufferer and the cause of his sufferings, but they also diminish the inward swelling of the heart;
tgt_text.8127: but in the time of excessive sorrow, tears take to flight and are traitors to the eyes;
tgt_text.8128: sorrow encounters them as they are springing from their fountain, arrests their progress and compels them to retrace their way;
tgt_text.8129: accordingly, turned from the direction of the eyes they flow back upon the soul and exasperate its inward wounds.
tgt_text.8130: Turning to Leucippe, who had not spoken a word, I said, " Why are you silent, dearest?
tgt_text.8131: Why do you not speak to me ?" " Because," she replied, " though my soul still lives, my voice is already dead."
tgt_text.8132: The dawn imperceptibly over­ took us while we were engaged in conversation, when a horseman suddenly rode up with a profusion of long matted hair;
tgt_text.8133: ‡ his horse was as shaggy as himself and bare­ backed, without housings of any kind, as is customary with the horses of these buccaneers.
tgt_text.8134: He came it appeared from their captain, with orders to bring away any maiden whom he might find to be an expiatory offering on behalf of the pirates, to their god.
tgt_text.8135: The guards immediately seized Leu­ cippe, who clung to me with shrieks, but while some of them struck me, others tore her away, placed her on horse­ back and rode away, leaving us who were still bound to follow at greater leisure.
tgt_text.8136: We had scarcely proceeded two furlongs from the village when we heard a loud shouting mingled with the sounds of a trumpet, and presently a body of heavy armed soldiers appeared in view, upon which the pirates, placing us in the centre, stood their ground and prepared for resistance.
tgt_text.8137: The soldiers were about fifty in number, some bearing long shields reaching to the feet, others having only bucklers.
tgt_text.8138: The buccaneers, who were far superior in numbers, began to pelt the military with clods of earth :
tgt_text.8139: ∗ now, an Egyptian clod can do more execution than any other, for being of stony earth, it is at the same time heavy, rough, and jagged, can raise a swelling and inflict a wound.
tgt_text.8140: The soldiers relying upon the protection of their shields cared little for these missiles, and waiting till the buccaneers were tired with their exertions, they suddenly opened their ranks, when the light-armed darted out, each armed with a javelin and a sword, and so skilful was the aim that no one missed his mark ;
tgt_text.8141: the heavy-armed proceeded to support them and a stubborn fight took place, in which abundance of blows and wounds were exchanged on either side.
tgt_text.8142: Military discipline made up for deficiency of numbers, the pirates began to give ground, which, when we observed, I and the other prisoners bursting through their ranks went over to the enemy;
tgt_text.8143: ignorant of our real condition the soldiers were about to kill us, when per­ ceiving us to be naked and bound with cords, they received us into their ranks and sent us fcr safety to the rear;
tgt_text.8144: meanwhile a body of cavalry came up and extending their flanks they surrounded the buccaneers, got them into a nar­ row space and cut them down;
tgt_text.8145: the greater part were soon dispatched, some though severely wounded still resisted, the rest were taken prisoners.
tgt_text.8147: the commander of the forces, Oharmides by name, interrogated us severally, asking who we were, and how we had been captured.
tgt_text.8148: The others told their stories and I related my own adventures;
tgt_text.8149: after hearing every particular he desired us to follow him, promising to supply us with arms;
tgt_text.8150: it being his intention, as soon as the rest of his troops came up, to attack the chief haunt of the pirates, where it was said there were ten thousand men.
tgt_text.8151: Being a good rider I requested the favour of a horse, and no sooner was my wish complied with, than mounting I went through the different evolu­ tions of a cavalry soldier, to the great delight of the com­ mander.
tgt_text.8152: He insisted on having me as a guest at his own table, and after hearing my history at supper time, expressed his commiseration of my misfortunes.
tgt_text.8153: The listening to others' grief oftentimes begets sympathy in the hearers, and this sympathy leads to friendship, the soul affected by the relation of woe, passing from feelings of pity to sensations of a tenderer kind.∗
tgt_text.8154: Charmides, at any rate, was so much moved, that he could not refrain from tears;
tgt_text.8155: more than this he could not do, as Leucippe was in the power of the pirates.
tgt_text.8156: I may also mention that he kindly gave me an Egyptian as my servant.
tgt_text.8157: The next day he prepared to advance against the buccaneers, who were seen in great force on the other side of a trench which it was his object to fill up.
tgt_text.8158: They had constructed a rude altar of earth, and near it lay a coffin;
tgt_text.8159: two men were seen conducting the maiden, whose hands were bound behind her back.
tgt_text.8160: I could not distinguish who they were, because their armour concealed them, but I easily recognized Leucippe.
tgt_text.8161: After pouring a libation upon her head, they led her round the altar, an Egyptian priest all the while chanting a hymn as was evident from the motion of his lips and the muscles of his face ;
tgt_text.8162: ∗ when this was ended, all at a signal being given retired to a considerable distance, when one of the young men who had conducted the maiden placed her upon the ground, bound her to four wooden pegs-just as image makers represent Marsyas bound to the tree-and then drawing a sword plunged it into her heart, and drawing the weapon downwards laid open all her belly so that the intestines immediately protruded;
tgt_text.8163: then they removed and laid them upon the altar, and when roasted they were cut into portions and partaken of by the pirates.
tgt_text.8164: The sol­ diers and their commander upon witnessing these proceed­ ings cried out and averted their faces in disgust;
tgt_text.8165: strange to say, I continued to gaze in stupid astonishment, as if thunderstruck by the surpassing horror of the spectacle.
tgt_text.8166: There may really have been some truth in the legend of Niobe, and from being affected by the loss of her children, in the same way in which I was now, her motionless ap­ pearance may have given her the appearance of being turned to stone.
tgt_text.8167: When the horrible business was, as I supposed ended, the young men placed the body in the coffin, covering it with a lid, and after throwing down the altar, hurried back to their companions, not once looking behind them, for such had been the injunction of the priest.
tgt_text.8168: By evening the trench was filled up and the soldiers after crossing it, encamped for the night and prepared their supper.
tgt_text.8169: Charmides seeing my distress, did all in his power to console me, but to no purpose;
tgt_text.8170: for about the first watch of the night, when all were asleep, I took my sword, pro­ ceeded to the spot and prepared to stab myself upon the coffin.—“Wretched Leucippe," I exclaimed, " thou most ill-fated of human kind, I lament not so much thy death, nor thy dying in a foreign land, nor that it has been a death of violence;
tgt_text.8171: but that such insults have been heaped upon thy misfortunes-that thou hast been made a victim to purify the most polluted of their kind-that thou hast been ripped up while yet alive, and able to gaze upon the horrid process -that thou hast had an accursed altar and coffin for thy joint grave, the former for thy bowels, the latter for thy oody.
tgt_text.8172: Had the fire consumed thy entrails, there would be less cause to grieve;
tgt_text.8173: but now, most horrible, they have been made to furnish forth food to a pirate band!
tgt_text.8175: and yet the gods looked quietly down upon such proceedings,.
tgt_text.8176: and yet the fire was not extinguished, but polluted as it was sent up its odour with acceptance to the deities!
tgt_text.8177: Leucippe, thou shalt now receive from me the offering which bents thee."
tgt_text.8178: After uttering these words, I raised the sword and was oil the point of stabbing myself, when by the light of the moon I perceived two men hastily running towards me;
tgt_text.8179: supposing them to be buccaneers, I paused in the ex­ pectation of being put to death by them ;
tgt_text.8180: they soon reached the spot where I was standing and both called aloud to me, and who should they prove to be, but Satyrus and Mene­ laus.
tgt_text.8181: So profound was my grief at what had taken place, that though I saw before me two of my friends unex­ pectedly alive and well, I neither embraced them nor felt any emotion of joy.
tgt_text.8182: Seizing my hand they endeavoured to wrest the sword from me.
tgt_text.8183: “ In the name of the gods," said I, “ grudge me not a welcome death, or rather, I should say, a medicine for all my ills.
tgt_text.8185: I will no longer remain in life, now that Leucippe is gone.
tgt_text.8186: You may indeed deprive me of this weapon, but there will remain a sword of grief within which slowly kills and drinks my blood;
tgt_text.8187: do you wish that I should die by this slow and lingering death ?
tgt_text.8188: Upon this, interrupting me, Menelaus said, " If this be your only reason for dying, you may put up your sword;
tgt_text.8189: Leucippe shall soon come to life again."
tgt_text.8190: I looked stead­ fastly at him, and exclaimed, " Can you insult me in the midst of such calamities (-have some regard for hospitable Jove."
tgt_text.8191: Without farther delay he tapped upon the coffin several times, calling out, "Leucippe, since Clitopho is incre­ dulous, do you bear witness to the truth of what I say;
tgt_text.8192: " and almost immediately a faint voice was heard proceeding from the interior.
tgt_text.8193: A sudden trembling seized me, and I gazed upon Menelaus, half believing him to be a sorcerer;
tgt_text.8194: he proceeded to remove the lid, when Leucippe slowly rose and came forth, presenting the most fearful spectacle which can be imagined;
tgt_text.8195: the lower part of her person was entirely laid open and all her bowels had been removed;

tgt_text.8433: Menelaus and those present did all they could to comfort me, saying that such maladies were not lasting, and were very common in the hot season of youth;
tgt_text.8434: at such a time the young blood, heated by the vigour of the body, runs boiling through the veins, and overflowing the brain drowns the powers of reason ;
tgt_text.8435: the proper course, therefore, would be to have medical advice.
tgt_text.8436: Menelaus went to the commander without delay, and requested that the physician belonging to tho troops might be called in.
tgt_text.8437: Charmides readily complied, for a lover delights in granting favours.
tgt_text.8438: After visiting her, he said, we must make her sleep in order to subdue the paroxysm of her disease;
tgt_text.8439: for sleep is the medicine of every sickness,* and afterwards we will have recourse to other means.
tgt_text.8440: Before leaving her, he gave us a portion of some drug, about the size of a pea, which was to be dissolved in oil and rubbed upon the top of her head, saving that he would shortly bring a pill to act upon her bowels.
tgt_text.8441: We followed his directions, and after her head had been rubbed for a short time, she fell asleep, and slept till morning.
tgt_text.8442: I sat by her bed side all night in tears, and when I saw the cords which still confined her hands, I could not help exclaiming, " Dearest Leucippe, bondage is still thy por­ tion ;
tgt_text.8443: not even in sleep is liberty allowed thee!
tgt_text.8444: What images, I wonder, are now passing before thy mind ?
tgt_text.8445: Does sense attend upon thy sleep ?
tgt_text.8446: or do thy dreams also partake of frenzy ?"
tgt_text.8447: Upon waking she uttered some incoherent words.
tgt_text.8448: Soon after the physician came and administered the other medicine.
tgt_text.8449: Just at this time pressing orders arrived from the Vice­ rov of Egypt urging the commander to lead his men against the enemy.
tgt_text.8450: The troops were immediately mustered­ with their officers, and appeared on the ground in marching order, when, after giving them the watchword, he dismissed them to their quarters for the night, and next morning led them out to battle.
tgt_text.8451: I will now describe the nature of the district against which they marched.
tgt_text.8452: The Nile flows in an unbroken stream from Egyptian Thebes as far as Memphis, when it throws out a small branch.
tgt_text.8453: Where the wide part of the river ter­ minates, stands the village Cercasorum*;
tgt_text.8454: there the country becomes intersected by three streams;
tgt_text.8455: two flowing respec­ tively to the right and left;
tgt_text.8456: the other continuing its onward course traverses the district called the Delta;
tgt_text.8457: none of these streams flow uninterruptedly to the sea, but upon reaching different cities separate into various branches, all of them larger than any Grecian rivers;
tgt_text.8458: its waters nevertheless are not enfeebled and rendered useless by the many divisions in their course;
tgt_text.8459: they bear vessels upon their surface ;
tgt_text.8460: they are used for drinking, and contribute to fertilize the land.
tgt_text.8461: The mighty Nile is all in all to the Egyptians, both land and river, and sea and lake, and a singular spectacle it is to see in juxtaposition the ship and the mattock, the oar and the plough, the rudder and the hook,. sailors' cabins and labourers' huts, a resort for fishes and a resting-place for oxen;
tgt_text.8462: where but lately a ship sailed, is seen a cultivated plain, and anon the cultivated plain becomes a watery space ;
tgt_text.8463: for the Nile periodically comes and goes, and the Egyptians count the days and anxiously await the inundation, while the river on his part keeps to his appointed time, regulates the rising of his waters, and never exposes himself to the imputation of unpunctuality.
tgt_text.8464: Then comes the rivalry between the land and water;
tgt_text.8465: each exerts its power against the other;
tgt_text.8466: the water strives to flood the land, and the land does its endeavour to absorb the fertilizing water;
tgt_text.8467: in the end, conquest can be assigned to neither, but both may claim the victory, for each is co-extensive with the other.
tgt_text.8468: In the pasturage which is the resort of the buccaneers, a quantity of water is at all times found, for even when the Nile retires, the lakes formed by its inundation continue filled with watery mud ;
tgt_text.8469: over these the inhabitants can either wade on foot or pass in boats, each of which will contain one person;
tgt_text.8470: any other kind would be imbedded in the mud, but those which they employ are so light† as to require very little water, and should none be found they take them on their backs, and proceed on foot until they arrive at more.
tgt_text.8471: These lakes, which I have mentioned, are dotted over with islets, some of them uninhabited, but abounding in papyrus reeds, between the intervals of which there is only room for a man to stand, while the space above is overarched by the summits of the leaves;
tgt_text.8472: it is in these places that the buccaneers assemble, and secretly concert their plans, masked by these reeds as by a fort.
tgt_text.8473: Some of the islets have huts upon them, presenting the appearance of a rudely constructed town, which serve as the dwellings of the pirates.
tgt_text.8474: One of them, more remarkable than the other for its extent and for the number of its huts, was called Nicochis, and here it was that the main body of the freebooters was collected;
tgt_text.8475: confiding in their numbers, and in the strength of their position, the place being entirely insulated by lagoons, except for a narrow causeway the eighth of a mile long and seventy feet wide.
tgt_text.8476: As soon as they weie aware of the commander's approach, they had recourse to the following stratagem :
tgt_text.8477: —mustering all the old men, they equipped them as suppliants, with palm branches, commanding the most able-bodied among the youth to follow, armed with swords and shields.
tgt_text.8478: The old men were to hold aloft their suppliant branches, the foliage of which would serve to conceal those in the rear,* who, by way of farther precaution, were directed to stoop and trail their spears along the ground.
tgt_text.8479: In case the commander yielded to the old men's suppli­ cations, the others were to make no hostile movements;
tgt_text.8480: if, on the contrary, he should reject their entreaties, they were to invite liin to their city, with the offer of there surrender­ ing themselves up to death;
tgt_text.8481: if he agreed to follow them, upon arriving at the middle of the narrow causeway, the old men, at a preconcerted signal, were to throw away their branches and make their escape, while the others were to make an assault with might and main.
tgt_text.8482: They proceeded to execute these directions, and upon approaching the corn.
tgt_text.8483: mander, entreated him to reverence their old age and suppliant branches, and to take pity upon their town ;
tgt_text.8484: they offered him a present of a hundred talents of silver for him­ self, together with an hundred hostages, to be forwarded by him to the seat of goverment.t
tgt_text.8485: They were quite sincere in making these proposals, and would have fulfilled them faithfully had he consented ;
tgt_text.8486: upon his refusal, "We must then," said they, “ submit to our destiny;
tgt_text.8487: at least grant us this one favour:
tgt_text.8488: do not put us to death at a distance from our town, conduct us to our ‘ fatherland,’ to our hearths and homes, and there let us find our grave.
tgt_text.8489: We ourselves are ready to lead the way!
tgt_text.8490: Upon hearing these words, Charmides laid aside his dis­ positions for battle, and ordered his forces to follow leisurely.
tgt_text.8491: The buccaneers had meanwhile posted some scouts at a distance, who were to watch the movements of the enemy, and who, when they bad reached the causeway, were to let out the waters upon them.
tgt_text.8492: The canals which issue from the branches of the Nile have high banks, to hinder the river from flooding the land before the time, and when the fields require watering, a portion of the bank is cut through.
tgt_text.8493: Now there was a long and wide canal behind the town which we are speaking of;
tgt_text.8494: those who were stationed for the purpose cut through the banks as soon as they saw the enemy approaching, and in a moment the old men fled, the others charged with their spears, on rolled the waters rising higher and higher, the causeway was flooded, and all around became a sea.
tgt_text.8495: The buccaneers at the first onset speared the foremost of the enemy, together with their commander, who were taken by surprise, and therefore quite unprepared, and it is difficult to describe the various ways in which the others perished.
tgt_text.8496: Some fell before they could even handle their weapons;
tgt_text.8497: some before they could offer any resist­ ance ;
tgt_text.8498: for to see their assailants and to receive their own death-wound was simultaneous ;
tgt_text.8499: others were slain before they could see the hand which slew them;
tgt_text.8500: some overcome by terror, remained motionless awaiting death;
tgt_text.8501: others upon attempting to move were taken off their legs by the force of the stream, while others again, who had betaken themselves to flight, were carried along and drowned in the deep part of the lagoons, where the water was above their heads ;
tgt_text.8502: those even who were upon land had water up to their middles, which, by turning aside their shields, exposed their bodies to the enemy.
tgt_text.8503: The difficulty of know­ Ing what was land and what was not, retarded many, and was the cause of their being taken prisoners;
tgt_text.8504: while others supposing themselves still on land came into deep water and were drowned;
tgt_text.8505: here were to be seen mishaps and wrecks of an unwonted kind,-a land engagement on the water, and a wreck upon the land.
tgt_text.8506: *The buccaneers were greatly elated by their success, and attributed their victory not to fraud but to their own valour;
tgt_text.8507: for among the Egyptians their fear degenerates into abject cowardice, and their courage mounts to rash­ ness ;
tgt_text.8508: in this respect they are always iu extremes, and are wholly subject either to the excess or the defect.
tgt_text.8509: Ten days had now passed and Leucippe was no better;
tgt_text.8510: upon one occasion while asleep she cried out in a frenzied manner, " Gorgias, it is thou who hast driven me mad !”†
tgt_text.8511: I told Menelaus of this in the morning, and began to consider whether there was any one in the village of that name.
tgt_text.8512: We were just going out, when a young man met and accosted me, saying, "I am come to save you and your wife."
tgt_text.8513: Perfectly astounded, and thinking that his coming was providential, " Are you Gorgias ?" I inquired.—“ No," replied he, "my name is Chæreas ;
tgt_text.8514: Gorgias is the cause of all the mischief."
tgt_text.8515: I felt a thrill run through me, as I asked, "What mischief do you mean?
tgt_text.8517: Some deity betrayed his name to me last night;
tgt_text.8518: be you an interpreter of the announcement."“Gorgias," ho resumed, " was an Egyptian soldier;
tgt_text.8519: he is now no more, having been slain by the buccaneers.
tgt_text.8520: lie conceived a passion for your wife, and being well acquainted with the nature of drugs, he compounded a love philtre which he persuaded your Egyptian servant to mix with Leucippe's drink ;
tgt_text.8521: he neglected to dilute the potion, so that instead of producing love it brought on madness.
tgt_text.8522: I was informed of all this yesterday by Gorgias' servant, who accompanied his master against the buccaneers, and who seems to have been specially preserved by Fortune for your sake.
tgt_text.8523: He asks four pieces of gold for effecting your wife's recovery, having, as he says, a drug which will counteract the effects of that which has been administered." " All blessings attend you for this good service !”
tgt_text.8525: “pray bring the man here of whom you speak.
tgt_text.8526: "No sooner was he departed on this errand, than going in to the Egyptian, I struck him repeatedly about the head with my clenched fist, saying at every blow, "What was it which you gave Leucippe ?
tgt_text.8527: What is it which has caused her madness ?"
tgt_text.8528: The fellow in his fright confessed every­ thing, confirming what Chæreas had already said;
tgt_text.8529: upon which we thrust him into prison, and there kept him.
tgt_text.8530: By this time Chæreas had returned, bringing the man with him. "
tgt_text.8531: Here are your four gold pieces as the reward for your seasonable information ;
tgt_text.8532: but before you proceed to do anything, hear my opinion.
tgt_text.8533: As this lady's illness has been caused by swallowing a drug, I cannot but think it danger­ ous to administer more physic while the stomach is already under the influence of medicine;
tgt_text.8534: tell me, therefore, what are the ingredients in your proposed remedy, and compound it in my presence;
tgt_text.8535: upon these conditions I will give you four more gold pieces." " Your apprehensions are reason­ able," he replied;
tgt_text.8536: " but the ingredients in my medicine are all common and fit for human food, and I will myself swallow the same quantity which I give the lady."
tgt_text.8537: After specifying the various ingredients, he sent some one out to procure them;
tgt_text.8539: soon as they were brought, he pounded them together in our presence, made two draughts of them, saying, " one of them I will drink off, the other is for the lady;
tgt_text.8540: it will make her sleep all night, and in the morning she will awake quite recovered."
tgt_text.8541: He then swal­ lowed the draught, and ordered the other to be taken at night. " I must now go and lie down," he said, " under the influence of the medicine."
tgt_text.8542: With these words he left us, having received the stipulated sum, and with the assurance of the additional reward being paid him, if Leu­ cippe should recover.
tgt_text.8543: When the hour arrived for adminis­ tering the draught, I poured it out, and thus addressed it :
tgt_text.8545: Esculapius, mâÿ the pro­ mises made of thee be verified;
tgt_text.8546: shew thyself propitious and preserve my beloved;
tgt_text.8547: subdue the power of that ruthless potion."
tgt_text.8548: Thus having entered into a kind of compact with the medicine, I kissed the cup and give it to Leucippe.
tgt_text.8549: She soon fell into a profound sleep, and while sitting beside her I said to her, as if she could still hear me, “ Wilt thou really recover thy senses ?
tgt_text.8551: Shall I hear that dear voice of thine ?
tgt_text.8552: Give some token in thy sleep, as yesternight thou didst concerning Gorgias;
tgt_text.8553: happier are thy sleeping than thy waking hours;
tgt_text.8554: frenzy is thy portion when awake, but thou art inspired by Wisdom when asleep.
tgt_text.8555: At length my words and thoughts were interrupted by the anxiously-expected break of day, and I heard Leucippe's voice calling me by name.
tgt_text.8556: Instantly I hurried to her side, and inquired how she felt;
tgt_text.8557: she appeared to have no know­ ledge of what had passed, and seeing that her hands were bound, expressed surprise, and inquired who had tied them.
tgt_text.8558: Finding her restored to her right mind, I undid the knots in great agitation, through excess of joy, and then related to her all particulars.
tgt_text.8559: She blushed upon learning what bad passed, and almost believed herself to be still committing the same extravagance ;
tgt_text.8560: but my assurances gradually soothed and restored her to herself.
tgt_text.8561: Gladly did I pay the man the sum which had been promised him, and fortunately our finances * were in safety, for Satyrus had our money about his person† at the time when we were shipwrecked, and neither he nor Menelaus had been plundered by the buc­ caneers.
tgt_text.8562: While what I have been relating took place, a much more powerful force arrived from the seat of govern­ ment, which succeeded in completely destroying the pirate settlement.
tgt_text.8563: As the river was now freed from any dangers on the part of these marauders, we prepared to sail for Alexandria, accompanied by Chæreas, for whom we had conceived a friendship on account of the discovery which he had made to us about the potion.
tgt_text.8564: He was a native of the Isle of Pharos, and his calling that of a fisherman;
tgt_text.8565: he had served in a naval expedition against the buccaneers, and at its termination had been discharged.
tgt_text.8566: The river which, owing to the depredations of the pirates, had for a long time been deserted, was now crowded with vessels;
tgt_text.8567: and a pleasant thing it was to hear the songs of the sailors and the mirth of the passengers, and to see so many craft passing up and down.
tgt_text.8568: Our voyage was like a continuous festival, and the river itself seemed to be keeping holiday..
tgt_text.8569: I for the first time drank some of the Nile water, without any admixture of wine, being desirous to test its sweetness,-and wine, I may remark, always spoils the flavour of water.
tgt_text.8570: Having filled a transparent crystal glass, the liquid vied with, nay, surpassed it in brightness.
tgt_text.8571: It was sweet to the taste, and had an agreeable coldness, whereas some of the Grecian rivers are so very cold as to be injurious to the health.
tgt_text.8572: On this account the Egyptians have no fear in drinking its water, and stand in no need of wine. †
tgt_text.8573: Their way of drinking struck me as being curious.
tgt_text.8574: They do not draw up the water in a bucket, neither do they use any other cup than that which Nature has supplied,-their hand ;
tgt_text.8575: when any one is thirsty he stoops over the side of the vessel, and, receiving the water in the hollow of his hand, jerks it upwards with such dexterity, that it is received into the open mouth, and not a drop is lost.
tgt_text.8576: The Nile produces another monster, more noted for strength than even the river-horse, I mean the crocodilo.:
tgt_text.8577: His shape is between that of a fish and a large animal.
tgt_text.8578: Ills length from head to tail is great, and out of proportion to his breadth;
tgt_text.8579: his skin is rough with scales;
tgt_text.8580: the surface of his back hard and of a black colour, while the belly is white.
tgt_text.8581: He has four legs, which bend in an oblique direction, like those of the land tortoise;
tgt_text.8582: his tail is long and thick, forming a solid mass, and differing from that of other animals in being the continuation of the spine, and there­ fore a constituent part of the body, and on the top it is set with sharp spines, like the teeth of a saw.
tgt_text.8583: It serves the crocodile for an implement with which to capture his prey;
tgt_text.8584: he strikes with it against his antagonist, and a single stroke will inflict several wounds.
tgt_text.8585: His head grows directly out of his shoulders in one line, for Nature has concealed his neck.-
tgt_text.8586: The most formidable part about him are his jaws, which open to an immense extent;
tgt_text.8587: so long as they remain closed they form a head, but when expanded to take in its prey, they become all mouth;
tgt_text.8588: (the animal, I may observe, moves only the upper jaw) for so great is their expansion that it reaches to the shoulders and to the orifice of the stomach.
tgt_text.8589: He has many teeth, which are disposed in long rows :
tgt_text.8590: they are said to equal the days of the year in number.
tgt_text.8591: Were you to see the animal on land, you would not suppose him to be possessed of so much strength, judging from his size.
tgt_text.8592: WE arrived at Alexandria after a three days' passage.
tgt_text.8593: I entered by the gate of the Sun, and was at once amazed and delighted by the splendour of the city.
tgt_text.8594: A row of columns, on either side, led in a straight line to the gate of the Moon—these two divinities being the guardian gods of the city gates.
tgt_text.8595: In the midst of these columns was the open part of the city, which branched out into so many streets, that in traversing them, one seemed journeying abroad though all the time at home.†
tgt_text.8596: Proceeding a little farther I came to a part named after the great Alexander;
tgt_text.8597: here began a second city and its beauty was of a twofold kind, two rows of columns equal in extent, intersecting each other at right angles.
tgt_text.8598: It was impossible to satisfy the eye with gazing upon the various streets, or to take in every object deserving of admiration;
tgt_text.8599: some of these one actually saw, others one was on the point of seeing;
tgt_text.8601: others, again, one would not willingly have missed seeing;
tgt_text.8602: those which were actually present nvetted one's gaze;
tgt_text.8603: those which were anticipated tempted it to wander:
tgt_text.8604: after turning my eyes therefore, on every side, so distracted were my feelings of admiration, that I owned my eight to be thoroughly bewildered and unequal to its task.
tgt_text.8605: What most struck me was the extent of the city and its vast population, each of which in turn bore away the palm when compared with the other;
tgt_text.8606: the former seemed actually a country, the latter, a nation.
tgt_text.8607: When I looked at the vast size of the city, I doubted whether any number of inha­ bitants could till it;
tgt_text.8608: and when I considered the multitude of the inhabitants, I asked myself whether any city could contain them ;
tgt_text.8609: so evenly balanced was the calculation,.
tgt_text.8610: and so difficult was it to come to a decision.
tgt_text.8611: It chanced at that time to be the festival of the great deity called Jove by the Greeks, Serapis † by the Egyptians;
tgt_text.8612: torches were lighted up throughout the city, and the effect of so much light was marvellous, for although evening had come on and the sun had set, there was no such thing as night, another sun might be said to have arisen, only that his rays were scattered,‡ so that the city vied with heaven in brightness.
tgt_text.8613: I also visited the magnificent temple and saw the statue of the Milichian Jove, and after paying our devotions to his great divinity, and praying him to end at last, our troubles, we returned to the lodgings which Mene­ aus had engaged for us.
tgt_text.8614: The deity, as will be seen, did not hearken to our prayers, and another trial of fortune yet awaited us.
tgt_text.8615: Chæreas bad for some time been enamoured of Leucippe, which was his motive for communicating to me the circumstance of the philtre, by doing which he hoped to become on intimate terms with us and to preserve her life for his own ends.
tgt_text.8616: Knowing how difficult success would be, he had recourse to stratagem.
tgt_text.8617: Being a seafaring man, he had no difficulty in getting together some fellows, half-fishermen half-pirates, with whom he arranged what was to be done, and then under pretence of keeping his birth-day, he invited us to an entertainment at Pharos.
tgt_text.8618: As we were leaving the house a sinister omen befell us;
tgt_text.8619: a hawk pursuing a sparrow struck Leucippe on the cheek with its wing;
tgt_text.8620: alarmed at the occurrence I looked up towards heaven and said—“
tgt_text.8622: If this bird be indeed sent by thee, show us, I pray, some clearer augury."
tgt_text.8623: Upon turning round, I found myself standing by a painters shop where was a picture, the sub­ ject of which was in keeping with what had just taken place;
tgt_text.8624: it represented the rape of Philomela, the cruelty of Tereus in cutting out her tongue, every particular of the sad drama was seen depicted on the tapestry,.
tgt_text.8625: which was being held up by a female slave.
tgt_text.8626: Philomela stood pointing to the different figures which were worked upon it, and Procne was intimating that she understood her, at the same time casting stern and angry looks upon the picture.
tgt_text.8627: There, the Thracian Tereus was seen struggling with Philo­ mela, whose hair was dishevelled, her girdle loose, her dress torn, her bosom half naked;
tgt_text.8628: her right hand was planted against the face of Tereus, with her left she was endeavour­ ing to pull her torn dress over her breast;
tgt_text.8629: Tereus was holding her in his arms, drawing her person towards him, and embracing her as closely as ho could.
tgt_text.8630: Such was the subject of the tapestry.
tgt_text.8631: In the remainder of the painting, were seen the two sisters showing Tereus the relics of his supper, the head and bands of his own child;
tgt_text.8632: fear and bitter laughter are depicted on their faces;
tgt_text.8633: Tereus is leaping up from his couch and drawing his sword against them, and he has struck out his foot against the tablo # which neither stands nor falls, but seems in the very act of falling.
tgt_text.8635: In my opinion," said Menelaus, " we should give up the excursion to Pharos, for we have encountered two unfavourable omens, the hawk's wing and the threatening picture;
tgt_text.8636: now those who profess to interpret such matters, bid us pay regard to the subjects of any pictures which we may happen to meet with, when setting out on any business, and to conjecture the result of our undertaking from the nature of what we see.
tgt_text.8637: Did you not observe how full of evil augury this picture is ?
tgt_text.8638: There is depicted in it lawless love, shameless adul­ tery and female misery;
tgt_text.8639: we ought therefore to defer our expedition."
tgt_text.8640: I concurred in opinion with him, and we excused ourselves from accompanying Chrereas on that occasion;
tgt_text.8641: he left us, very much vexed at our determination, saying he should come to us the next day.
tgt_text.8642: Women are naturally fond of hearing stories, accordingly when he was gone, Leucippe turning to me said, " Pray tell me what is the subject represented in this picture?
tgt_text.8645: and who is that shameless man ?” I proceeded to gratify her wishes.—
tgt_text.8646: “The hoopoe," I said, " was once a man called Tereus, the swallow and the nightingale were two sisters named Phi­ lomela and Procne, natives of Athens.
tgt_text.8647: One woman, it seems, is not enough for a barbarian, especially when an occasion offers for gratifying his lust;
tgt_text.8648: and such an oppor­ tunity was offered to Tereus through the sisterly affection of Procne, who sent her husband to invite Philomela;
tgt_text.8649: he conceived a passion for her, on his way back, made her a second Procne;
tgt_text.8650: then fearing lest she should reveal the deed, he, as the reward for her virginity deprives her of speech by cutting out her tongue, our nature's glory.t
tgt_text.8651: The precaution was fruitless, Philomela, by her skill contrived a silent voice;
tgt_text.8652: she inwove the tragedy into a web, descrip­ tive of the facts, her hand supplying the place of a tongue, and revealing to her sister's eyes what otherwise would have been whispered into her ears.
tgt_text.8653: Procne, learning through this device the violence which had been perpe­ trated, determines to take fearful vengeance;
tgt_text.8654: and two angry women's minds, conspiring together, and influenced by mingled feeling of jealousy and sense of wrong, contrive a supper more detestable even then the rape..
tgt_text.8655: They serve up to the father his own child ;
tgt_text.8656: Procne had once been his mother, now she had forgotten the maternal tie, so power.
tgt_text.8657: fully do the pangs of jealousy prevail over those even of travail;
tgt_text.8658: for women, when exacting satisfaction for a violated bed, however deeply they may suffer in what they do, com­ pensate the pain by the pleasure of inflicting vengeance.!
tgt_text.8659: Tereus supped upon this hellish banquet, and afterwards the sisters, trembling with fear yet laughing horribly, bring in the remnants of his child upon a dish.
tgt_text.8660: He recog­ nizes the miserable tokens, curses the food which he had swallowed, and discovers himself to be the father of what he had been feasting on.
tgt_text.8661: Maddened with fury, he draws his sword, and is in the act of rushing upon the women, when lo!
tgt_text.8662: the air receives them metamorphosed into birds.
tgt_text.8663: Tereus also becomes a bird, and ascends after them ;

tgt_text.8665: We had for once escaped the snare laid for us, but we gained by it only a single day, for next morning Chæreas arrived, and feeling ashamed to make any more excuses we went on board a vessel and sailed to Pharos.

tgt_text.9606: "The syrinx is composed of a certain number of reed pipes, which collectively produce the same sounds as a flute;
tgt_text.9607: these reeds are placed in regular order and mutually compacted, presenting the same appearance on either side;
tgt_text.9608: beginning from the shortest, they ascend in gradation to the longest, and the central one holds a medium proportion between the two extremities.
tgt_text.9609: The principle of this arrange­ ment arises from the laws of harmony, the two extremes of sound (as well as of length) are found at either end, and the intervening pipes convey downwards a gradation of notes so as to combine the first and shrillest with the last and deepest of all.
tgt_text.9610: The same variety of sounds, (as before observed) are produced by Minerva's flute* as by the syrinx of are;
tgt_text.9611: but in the former case, the fingers direct the notes, in the latter, the mouth supplies the place;
tgt_text.9612: in the one case, the performer closes every opening except the one through which the breath is intended to proceed;
tgt_text.9613: in the other case, he leaves open the aperture of every other reed, and places his mouth upon that one only which he wishes to emit a sound ;
tgt_text.9614: his lips leap (as we may say) from reed to reed and dance t along the syrinx;
tgt_text.9615: as the laws of harmony require.‡
tgt_text.9616: Now, this syrinx was originally neither pipe nor reed, but a damsel* whose charms made her most desirable.
tgt_text.9617: Smitten by love, Pan pursued her, and she fled for refuge to a thicket;
tgt_text.9618: the god still closely following her, stretched forth his hand to seize as he supposed her hair, but lo!

tgt_text.9620: Enraged at his disappointment, Pan cut them down, imagining that they had stolen from him the object of his love;
tgt_text.9621: but when his search after her still proved unavailing, he supposed the maiden to have been changed into these reeds, and wept at his hasty act, thinking that in so doing he had caused the death of his beloved.
tgt_text.9622: He then proceeded to collect and place together what he imagined to be her limbs, and holding them in his hands, continued to kiss what fancy pictured to be the mangled remains of the maiden's body.
